loans.name: Para

texts.en:
Para K. lives in a single family with her husband and two children in Koteshwor. Her husband's name is Lalit K. and he works in a private office. They have one son and one daughter. Both of them are studying in secondary school.
Para opened her bag shop three years ago to help her husband in fulfilling the household expenses. She sells different types of bags like school and ladies bags in her shop. She buys these bags from the wholesale market. Now she is requesting a  $300 loan to expand her shop. She wants to buy different varieties of bags.
Para wants to use her income for her children’s education and she also wants to upgrade the living standard of her family.

loans.use: To buy bags

loans.name: Puanam

texts.en:
Punam M. has two daughters. Her daughters are studying in grade 9 and 6 respectively. Her husband's  name is Bharat M. and he works in a shoe shop. 
Punam M. opened her beauty parlor 3 years ago to earn something for herself. She took 3 month of training for this work from a training institute. She opened her beauty parlor in Koteshwor.  Her service is for ladies only. Now she is requesting a loan for $300 to buy various types of cosmetic goods for her work.  M. wants to use her income to increase the living standard of her family. She also wants to provide a good education for her daughters.

loans.use: To buy cosmetic goods

loans.name: Ambica

texts.en:
Ambica P. lives in Koteshwor, Nepal. Koteshwor is located in the Kathmandu district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in their own businesses.  Ambica P. has four members including herself in her family. Her husband's name is Bhishma Raj P.. He works in a private office. They have two children. Her older son is studying in grade 10 and the younger son is studying in grade 9.
Two years ago Ambica opened her ready made clothes shop to uplift the living standard of her family. She sells different types of clothes in her shop. She specializes in children clothes. 
Now  Ambica is requesting a $300 loan to buy new design clothes for her shop.

loans.use: To buy clothes for her shop

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en: Sokha N., 57, and her husband, Chhout Aum, live on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River. Married for 31 years, they have four daughters. One of their daughters is married and lives at home with them; two sell silk goods in the village; and the other weaves silk at home. Sokha is requesting a loan of $400 U.S. dollars to buy wood and materials to build a house for her daughter.

loans.use: To buy wood to build a home

loans.name: Phally

texts.en:
Phally S., 35, and his wife, Sivorn Mok, 35, live in a village about 10 miles from Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. Married for 16 years, they have three young children who are in school.

Phally supports his family by working as a gardener in a hotel and also farms his own land in his free time. Sivorn works in a garment factory. They are requesting a loan of $1,000 U.S. dollars to dig a well and install a water pumping machine so his family can have clean drinking water. He also plans on using the water for his small farm.

loans.use: To dig a well for his family's drinking water and a small farm

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr:
Born in about 1948 in Porto-Novo in the Ouémé department in south-east Benin, Mrs. Christine D. is a widow and mother of four children. Three of her children are already grown up and are no longer dependent on her. She has always lived in Hindé 1, the district surrounding Dantokpa market. For about twenty years she has run a business selling condiments and various food products. In 2007 she took out an initial loan of 40,000 CFA Francs ($100) in order to increase her capital and make her display more attractive. This loan proved to be a great support as her business underwent a considerable improvement. She is currently requesting a third loan of 100,000 CFA Francs ($250) to better satisfy her customers who have come to her because her business is located close to Dantokpa market.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer.

Née vers 1948 à Porto-Novo dans le département de l'Ouémé au sud-ouest du Bénin, dame D. Christine est veuve et mère de quatre enfants. Trois de ses enfants sont déjà majeurs et ne sont plus à sa charge. Résidant à Hindé 1, quartier périphérique du marché de Dantokpa depuis sa naissance. Elle exerce comme activité la vente de condiments et de divers produits alimentaires il y a environ une vingtaine d’années. Afin de renforcer son capital et rendre plus attrayant son étalage, elle fit en 2007 un premier prêt de 40000F CFA. Ce crédit fut d’un grand appui pour elle car son activité a connu une amélioration considérable. Actuellement, elle sollicite pour son troisième prêt un montant de 100000F CFA pour mieux satisfaire ses clients qui sont devenus à cause de la proximité de son lieu d'activité avec le marché Dantokpa.

loans.use: To buy three boxes of canned tomatoes and 25 kg of dried peppers.

loans.name: Sily

texts.en:
Sily Y., 42, and her husband, Pha Sim, 45, a farmer, live in a small village on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River. Married for 18 years, the couple has one son and one daughter.

For the past decade, Sily has earned a living by weaving silk into cloth, a skill she learned from her parents. She sells her finished goods to a middle man in the village, who then takes it to sell in the capital city of Phnom Penh, which is about 10 miles away. In addition to her weaving business, hard-working Sily also runs a small grocery shop in the front of her home.

To grow her businesses, Sily is requesting a loan of $700 U.S. dollars to purchase more food to sell and silk to weave.

loans.use: To buy goods for a small grocery store and silk for weaving

loans.name: Sat's Group

texts.en:
Sat P. (shown at the far left, with the rest of her group members) was nominated to be a group leader for a loan. In a group loan, all the members split the loan equally and guarantee that each will repay her portion.

All of these women live in a small village on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River, about 10 miles north of the capital city of Phnom Penh. They all help support their families by weaving silk into cloth; a middle man takes their finished products to sell in Phnom Penh's markets. To grow their businesses, they plan on purchaing more raw silk to weave.

From right to left, Sat's group includes:

1. Sat P., 45, who has been a weaver for more than a decade, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She is married to Khun San, a mason; they have one son.

2. KhO. O., 20, is a newlywed. She and her husband, a construction worker, married last year. . 3. P. Pheap and her husband, a fisherman, have six children. 4. Sitha C., 27, and her husband, Vuthy Touch, a boat driver, married this year. 5. Sreynheb P., 42, is widow with three children, all of whom are garment factory workers. .

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.name: Sitha

texts.en:
Sitha H., 50, lives in a small village on Cambodia's Mekong River about 15 miles north of the capital city of Phnom Penh. A widow, Sitha has four daughters, three of whom are married and one who lives with her at home.

For the past 34 years, Sitha has supported her family by weaving silk into cloth, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished produts to a middle man in her village, who then resells it in Phnom Penh's markets. In addition to weaving, hard-working Sitha also grows rice to sell. To grow her businesses, Sitha is requesting a loan of $1,200 U.S. dollars to purchase more silk and rice.

loans.use: To purchase silk to weave and rice for a small farm

loans.name: Kakadé Lucie

texts.fr:
Native of Lokossa in the Mono department in south-west Benin, Mrs. Kakadé Lucie G. is 57 years old. She is married to Mr. Gabriel DEGBOGBAHOUN, a retired soldier, and is mother to five children. She does catering at the Suru-Léré School of General Education. In March 2004 she requested and was granted a first loan of 30,000 CFA Francs ($75) so that she could offer her clientele, made up mostly of pupils from the Suru-Léré school,  a varied and sufficiently well-balanced daily menu.  This experience proved very beneficial as, within a year, her working capital went from 50,000 CFA Francs ($125) to 85,000 CFA Francs ($210).  Other loans followed this first one. The only detriment to her career as a female entrepreneur has been her health, which was a little fragile in 2006, the year when she received a loan of 70,000 CFA Francs ($175). Her health has since improved and her business has returned to normal. She is therefore requesting her seventh loan to better position herself. 
 Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer.
Native de LOKOSSA dans le département du Mono au sud est du Bénin, dame G. Kakadé Lucie est âgée de 57ans. Mariée  à monsieur DEGBOGBAHOUN Gabriel, militaire à la retraite, elle est mère de cinq enfants. Elle fait de la restauration au Collège d’ Enseignement Général de Suru-Léré. Afin d’offrir à sa clientèle constituée pour la majorité des élèves de ce collège un menu journalier varié et suffisamment équilibré, elle a demandé et obtenu en mars 2004 un premier crédit de 30000F CFA. L’expérience lui fut très bénéfique car dans l’espace d’un an, son fonds de roulement est passé de 50000F CFA à 85000F CFA. D’autres prêts s’en sont suivis. La seule fausse note dans son parcours de femme entreprenante a été son état de santé qui s’était un peu fragilisé en 2006, année au cours de laquelle elle a reçu un prêt de 70000F CFA.  Son état de santé s'est amélioré depuis et ses activités sont redevenues normales. Elle vient donc solliciter son septième prêt pour mieux se positionner.

loans.use: To buy three 50-kg sacks of rice and two sacks of beans.

loans.name: Im

texts.en:
Mrs. Im N., 34, lives in Toul Vihear Village, Kampong Cham Province. She has been had a tailoring business with her husband for eight years, making approximately $5 per day. They both buy cloth, design painted shirts and sell them to customers. They work hard everyday to generate income to care for the living and education expenses of their three children. Due a growing tailoring business, they have a chance to generate more income. Therefore, they are requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase cloths stocks to make more shirts to sell.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase cloths

loans.name: Mawuenyégan Komivi

texts.fr:
Mr. Mawuényegan Komivi K. was born in Kévé on April 8, 1978. He is single and has no children. He is a merchant of generic goods. However, since 2007, he has specialized in the sale of Forever Living products; he received training for these products and he is able to offer his clients advice about them. At present time, he has a large number of clients who want to buy his products. Yet, Mr. K.’s working capital is insufficient to meet the demand. As a result, he is asking for this loan, his first, so he can increase his stock.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Monsieur K. Mawuényegan Komivi est né à Kévé le 08 avril 1978. Il est célibataire sans enfant. C’est un commerçant de produits génériques. Mais depuis 2007, il s’est spécialisé dans la vente des produits FOREVER LIVING, car il reçoit des formations sur les produits et sait conseiller les clients sur les produits. A présent, il dispose d’un nombre grandissant de clients qui ne cherchent qu’à être satisfaits. Mais le fonds de roulement dont dispose monsieur K. est insuffisant pour satisfaire la demande. Il sollicite alors ce premier crédit pour augmenter son stock.

loans.use: Purchase of health products

loans.name: Seok

texts.en:
Mrs. Seok C., 47, is a widowed grocery seller in Tonle Bet Krom Village, Kampong Cham Province. She earns around $2 per day and lives with her three children. One of her children is a driver for a private transportation company, while another works for a tobacco factory. Part of her children's income support the family's expenses. As C.’s business expands, she would like to request a loan of $200 to purchase more grocery stocks to sell. The loan will allow her to increase her income.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery stocks

loans.name: Ou

texts.en:
Mrs. Ou S., 31, is a mother of four children, living in Boeng Kok Village, Kampong Cham Province. She is a pig raiser earning around $3 per day, while her husband is a security guard at the market, earning around $3 per day. One of her children is a bricklayer, while another is car washer. Part of their children's income helps to support the family's expenses. Due to increasing transportation expenses, S. would like to request a loan of $1000 to purchase a second hand motorcycle for household use. With the remainder of the loan, she plans to purchase more pigs to raise. The loan will allow her family to increase their income.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase a second hand motorcycle

loans.name: Jeannette

texts.fr:
Born in about 1980 in Cotonou and married to Cyprien BODEHOUSSE, agent at the ‘les Cheminots’ pharmacy, Mrs. Jeannette H. is a mother with two children: Geoffroy, who is six years old and is in the first year of primary school (grade 1), and Abigaëlle who is three years old. She sells cookies, toothpaste and toothbrushes. She has been running this business for seven years and she lives with her husband in her parents’ house. She got to know our organization in 2007 when she had financial problems that were restricting her ability to purchase supplies. She received a total amount of 40,000 CFA Francs ($100) in her very first loan. Her business has grown considerably and her working capital has improved appreciably. For her third loan, she is requesting 100,000 CFA Francs ($250) to improve her business.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer.

Née vers 1980 à Cotonou et mariée à BODEHOUSSE Cyprien, agent à la pharmacie les Cheminots, dame H. Jeannette est mère de deux enfants. Geoffroy, 6ans est au Cours élémentaire 1 et Abigaëlle âgée de trois ans. Elle vend les biscuits, les pâtes dentifrices et les brosses à dents. Elle exerce cette activité depuis sept ans et habite la maison de ses parents avec son mari. Elle fit la connaissance de notre institution en 2007 à un moment où elle avait quelques difficultés financières qui l'handicapaient dans son approvisionnement. Elle avait reçu comme montant de son tout premier prêt 40000F CFA. Son activité s’est beaucoup développée et son fonds de roulement a été sensiblement amélioré. Pour son troisième prêt, elle sollicite 100000F CFA pour renforcer son activité.

loans.use: To buy three boxes of cookies and three dozen boxes of toothpaste.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok P., 28, is a farmer. She also sells bread with pork near her house. She makes about $1.8 per day. Her husband is a motorcycle taxi driver who makes around $2.5 per day. They have two children, and one is a textile worker whose income helps to support the family’s expenses. They all live in Andorng Chros Village in Kampong Cham Province. P. is requesting a loan of $300 to change her husband's motorcycle because it is old and does not attract customers.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL):

Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To change her husband's motorcycle to attract customers

loans.name: Rachelle

texts.fr:
Mrs. Rachelle S. was born on March 22, 1970 in Porto-Novo, the political capital of Benin, and is married to Casimir BODEHOUSSE who is a teacher. They have two children who both attend school. She has lived with her husband in the family home in the Sènadé II neighborhood of Cotonou for over 10 years. She runs a business selling food products and cloth tunics (pagnes) in front of her house. As an initial loan she received 60,000 CFA Francs ($150). She has since added the sale of cosmetics to her business activities and she is requesting 150,000 CFA Francs ($375) to lay in supplies.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer.

Dame S. Rachelle est née le 22 mars 1970 à Porto-Novo, la ville capitale politique du Bénin et mariée à BODEHOUSSE Casimir, un enseignant. Le couple a deux enfants tous scolarisés. Son mari et elle vivent dans une maison familiale au quartier Sènadé II à COTONOU depuis plus de dix ans. Elle exerce comme activité la vente de produits vivriers et de pagnes devant sa maison. Pour son premier prêt, elle a obtenu 60000F CFA. Elle a ajouté à ses activités la vente de produits cosmétiques et sollicite 150000F CFA pour s'approvionner.

loans.use: To purchase five 25-liter cans of vegetable oil and two dozen dressings.

loans.name: Grâce

texts.fr:
Born around 1978 in Cotonou, Ms. Grâce Y. is a mother of four children, three of whom are in school. These children are all in the care of their parents. Her husband is employed at SOBEBRA (Société Béninoise de Brasseries ). She sells various commonly consumed goods and vegetable oil. She has a shop in her home located in the Gankpodo district, not far from one of the branch offices of ALIDE. For her first loan, she is requesting the amount of 100,000 francs CFA enabling her to buy five drums of peanut oil. This loan will help her start her business and make it more competitive.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Née vers 1978 à Cotonou, dame Y. Grâce est mère de quatre enfants dont trois sont scolarisés. Ces enfants sont tous à la charge de leurs parents . Son mari est employé à la SOBEBRA (Société Béninoise de Brasseries ). Elle est vendeuse de divers produits de consommation courantes et d'huile végétale. Elle possède sa boutique en son domicile sis au quartier Gankpodo non loin de l'une des agences de ALIDé. Pour son premier crédit elle sollicite un montant de 100 000F CFA qui lui permettra d'acheter cinq bidons d'huile d'arachide. Ce prêt participera à l'émergence de son activité et la rendra beaucoup plus compétitive.

loans.use: To buy five drums of peanut oil

loans.name: Benkadi 1 (L’Entente Est Une Bonne Chose Group

texts.fr:
The Benkadi group is made up of married women who, on average, are 40 years old and have four children. They live in extended traditional families with their husbands, their husbands’ other wives, their brothers, their sisters, and their children in the village of Konobougou in the Baroueli prefecture (fourth largest administrative region in the Republic of Mali). They have a unique business which primarily consists of selling cloth, linens, children’s clothing, etc. They know each other through family and neighborly relations. The members of the Benkadi group are on their third loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, and all of the previous loans were repaid in full, allowing them to go from a first loan of 50,000 CFA francs to this loan of 100,000 CFA francs. They intend to buy cloth, clothing, shoes, etc. in Bamako and then sell them retail at the market in piles or spread out on tables. Their retail customers are primarily women. They would all like to open a clothing and linen shop at the market in Konobougou, which is located on an international roadway.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Le groupe Benkadi est constitué de femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’age de 40 ans et 4 enfants, vivant dans des familles élargies traditionnelles avec leurs maris, coépouses, frères, sœurs et enfants dans le village de Konobougou, Préfecture de Baroueli (4e région administrative de la République du Mali). Elles ont une activité économique un peu spéciale qui tourne essentiellement autour du commerce de pagnes, de parures et d’habillements pour enfants etc. Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Les membres du groupe Benkadi sont à leur troisième prêt avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Ainsi elles sont passées de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 100.000 FCFA au prêt actuel. Elles comptent acheter des pagnes, des habits et des chaussures etc. à Bamako pour les revendre en détail au marché dans des tasses ou sur des étales. La vente est faite en détail à une clientèle essentiellement composée de femmes. Elles souhaitent toutes ouvrir une boutique d’habillement et parures dans le marché de Konobougou situé sur une route internationale.

loans.use: Purchase of cloth and clothing

loans.name: Fatima

texts.fr:
Born around 1966, Ms. Fatima O. sells ready-to-eat meals (rice mixed with some beans, called "atassi” locally).  She is married and the mother of four.  Two of her children are in school, and the other two are in apprenticeships to learn a trade.  She is on her third loan and does make her payments.  For this loan, she is requesting 150,000 francs CFA, which will enable her to be consistently supplied with inventory in order to cover a big part of her orders, which are continuously growing.  Also, she would like to improve her sales outlet by building a shack to attract more customers.  Ms. Fatima O.’s sales outlet is located in the Saint Martin district, near her home.  Her daily turnover can be assessed at about 8,000 francs CFA.  

 Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer


Née vers 1966, dame O.  Fatima vend du repas prêt à manger (riz mélangé à du haricot localement appelé "atassi" ). Mariée, elle est mère de quatre enfants. Deux de ses enfants sont scolarisés et les deux autres sont à l'apprentissage d'un métier. Elle est à son troisième prêt et rembourse bien. Pour ce prêt, elle sollicite 150 000F CFA qui lui permettront de s'approvisionner de façon conséquente pour pouvoir couvrir une grande partie de sa demande qui ne cesse de s'accroître. Aussi, voudrait elle améliorer son lieu de vente par la construction d'une baraque pour attirer plus de clients. Dame O. Fatima a son lieu d'activité situé au quartier Saint Martin à proximité de son domicile. Son chiffre d'affaire journalier peut être évalué à environ 8 000F CFA.

loans.use: To buy a sack of rice, two boxes of pasta (macaroni), ten liters of peanut oil, and various condiments

loans.name: Benkadi 2 (L’Entente Est Une Bonne Chose Group

texts.fr:
The majority of the women in the Benkadi 2 group are married and, on average, are 22 years old and have two children. They live in extended traditional families with their husbands, their husbands’ other wives, and their children in the subprefecture of Konobougou (Ségou Region, Republic of Mali). Their business generally consists of selling all types of cloth (especially “Wax” cloth, which is highly sought after, particularly by women in Mali and in West Africa in general), children’s clothing, linens, etc. They were brought together by professional ties. Trusting one another, the members of the group decided to join Soro Yiriwaso, from which they are receiving their first group loan. They buy their products in the regional capital, Ségou, and sometimes in Bamako, and then sell them at the market in Konobougou on tables in warehouses to a primarily female clientele. “Wax” cloth is generally bought at 4,000 CFA francs per unit and then sold at 6,000 CFA francs, for a profit of 2,000 CFA francs. Their supplies are renewed monthly or as needed.

Translatde from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Les membres du groupe Benkadi 2 sont à majorité des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’age de 22 ans et 2 enfants qui vivent dans des familles conjugales élargies traditionnelles avec leurs époux, coépouses et enfants dans la sous préfecture de Konobougou (Région de Ségou, République du Mali). Elles font généralement le commerce de pagne de toutes sortes (surtout les pagnes Wax qui sont très prisés par les femmes du Mali en particulier et de l’Afrique de l’ouest en générale), de l’habillement pour enfants, de parures, etc. Elles se sont connues par des relations essentiellement professionnelles. Se faisant mutuellement confiance, les membres du groupe décidèrent d’intégrer le programme de crédit de l’institution de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur premier prêt solidaire. Elles vont s’approvisionner dans la capitale régionale, Ségou et quelquefois à Bamako pour venir vendre au marché de Konobougou sous des hangars avec des tables, à une clientèle essentiellement féminine. Les pagnes Wax sont achetés en général à 4.000 FCFA l’unité et revendu à 6.000 FCFA, soit une marge bénéficiaire de 2.000 FCFA. Le stock est renouvelé mensuellement ou au besoin.

loans.use: Purchase of cloth, linens and various items

loans.name: Sony

texts.en:
Sony S. and her husband, Voeun Krouch, live in a small village on the Mekong River about 10 miles north of Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. Married for 24 years, they have one son and four duaghters. Two of their children are married themselves; one son is a construction worker; and the youngest two daughters are in school.

For the past 16 years, Sony has helped support her family by weaving silk into cloth, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to a middle man in her village, who then resells it in Phnom Penh's markets. Meanwhile, Voeun is a mason.

To help grow her weaving business, Sony is requesting a loan of $300 U.S. dollars to purchase more silk.

loans.use: To buy silk for a weaving business

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en:
Sophea K., 32, lives in a small village on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River, about 10 miles from the capital city of Phnom Penh. She is single and resides with her aging parents and one brother.

Since she was 15, Sophea has supported herself and her family by weaving silk into cloth, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middle man in their village, who then resells it in Phnom Penh. To help grow her business, Sophea is requesting a loan of $200 U.S. dollars to buy more silk to weave.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.name: Benkadi 3 (L’Entente Est Une Bonne Chose). Group

texts.fr:
The women of the Benkadi group are married and, on average, are 35 years old and have five children. They live in traditional families with their husbands, generally their husbands’ other wives, and their children in Djinina, a village in the Fana subprefecture, Dioila prefecture, Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali. They all have small businesses that consist of selling food items, clothing, charcoal, fruits and vegetables, etc. They are primarily united by the fact that they live in the same village. Benkadi has been working with Soro Yiriwaso for four years and has obtained eight group loans which were all repaid in full. The group members who sell charcoal generally buy it in other villages and then sell it for cash on market days to business clients from Bamako or Ségou. The other women buy their condiments in Fana and then sell them retail in the village. With this loan, the women of the Benkadi group from Djinina, Fana hope to each earn a monthly profit of 10,000 CFA francs, which will be mostly used to pay off the interest on the loan and resolve some financial problems. The rest will be used for capital.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Les membres du groupe Benkadi sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’age de 35 ans et 5 enfants qui vivent dans de familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, généralement avec coépouses et des enfants dans le village de Djinina, un des villages de la sous préfecture de Fana, Préfecture de Dioila, Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali. Elles exercent toutes le petit commerce : de denrées alimentaires, d’habillements, de charbon de bois, de fruits et légumes etc. Elles sont essentiellement liées par des relations de voisinage. Benkadi est en relation avec Soro Yirwaso depuis maintenant 4 ans et a obtenu 8 prêts solidaires, tous correctement remboursés. Pour celles qui vendent du charbon de bois, elles s’approvisionnent généralement dans les villages et effectuent leurs ventes au comptant les jours de foires à une clientèle de commerçant provenant d Bamako ou de Ségou. Par contre, les autres s’approvisionnent en condiment à Fana pour les revendre au village en détail. Avec ce prêt les femmes du groupe Benkadi de Djinina, Fana espèrent avoir chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 10.000 FCFA qui sera essentiellement utilisé à payer les intérêts du prêt, à résoudre certains problèmes sociaux et le reste incorporé au capital.

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal and fruit

loans.name: Chanthol

texts.en:
Chanthol C., 31, and his wife, Vibol Rin, live in a small village about 10 miles from Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. Married for eight years, they have three young children, one son and two daughters.

For the past eight years, Chanthol has supported his family by driving a motorcycle taxi from his village to Phnom Penh, while Vibol works as a worker in a garment factory. The problem is that Chanthol's motorcycle is old, so it frequently breaks down.

Chanthol and Vibol are requesting a loan of $1,000. They plan on using a portion of that money to buy a new motorcycle, and spend the rest on building a bathroom in their home. Currently, their home has no restroom.

loans.use: For home repairs and to buy a new motorcycle for a taxi business

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Phalla N., 37, and her husband, Sam-Ol Mol, live in a small village about 10 miles from Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. Married for 17 years, they have two sons and one daughter. Two of their children are currently in school.

To help support her family, Phalla is woven silk into cloth, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a man in their village, who then sells in Phnom Penh's markets. Meanwhile, Sam-Ol works as a salesman.

Phalla and Sam-Ol have recently moved into a new house. Phalla is requesting a loan of $1,200 U.S. dollars to build a fence around their home, and also purchase more silk for weaving.

loans.use: For home repairs and to buy silk for weaving

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr:
Born on August 24, 1986 in Cotonou, Ms. Christine G. is a hairdresser by profession and the mother of two children, of whom the eldest is in her second year at the Cours Préparatoire. Her husband, an electronics technician, takes care of her children very well. Ms. Christine G.’s beauty salon is located in the Midombo district and on the edge of an open gutter, not far from the Midombo pharmacy. The good location of her place of business enables her to have good sale figures. The loan will allow her to stock up on hair extensions and other hair care products to meet the expectations of her customers better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Née le 24 Août 1986 à Cotonou, Dame G. Christine est coiffeuse de profession et mère de deux enfants dont l'aîné est au Cours Préparatoire deuxième année. Son mari, technicien en électronique s'occupe très bien de ses enfants. Le salon de beauté de dame G. Christine est situé au quartier Midombo au bord du caniveau à ciel ouvert non loin de la pharmacie Midombo. La bonne situation géographique de son lieu d'activité lui permet de faire un bon chiffre d'affaire. Ce crédit lui permettra de s'approvisionner en mèches et produits d'entretien de cheveux afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.

loans.use: To buy 30 sachets of hair extensions and 20 containers of hair cream

loans.name: Thy

texts.en:
Thy P., 30, and her husband, Sina Auk, 27, a construction worker, live on an island in the Mekong River, about 10 miles from Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. They were married eight years ago have one son and two daughters.

For more than a decade, Thy has earned a living by weaving silk into cloth, a skill she learned from her parents. She sells her finished products to a man in her village, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh's markets. In addition to weaving, entrepreneurial Thy also wants to start another business of selling vegetables in front of their home.

To help grow her businesses, Thy is requesting a loan of of $400 U.S. dollars to purchase more silk to weave and vegetables to resell. .

loans.use: To purchase silk to weave and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Sitha

texts.en:
Sitha H., 49, and his wife, Phally Pich, live in a village about 10 miles outside of Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. Married for 26 years, they have two sons and four daughters. For nearly three decades, Sitha has supported his family by driving a siklo, or a bicycle with a trailer in the front to carry people or goods. In Cambodia, most people use siklos or motorcycle taxis to get from place to place instead of taxis or buses.

Phally is a stay-at-home mother. Three of their children are still in school; two of their daughters work in a garment factory; and one of the sons also rides a siklo. To help drive his daughters to the factory, Sitha is requesting a loan of $300 U.S. dollars to purchase a motorcycle.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to drive their daughters to work

loans.name: Rim

texts.en:
Rim C., 32, and his wife, Sros Mony Kao, live in a village about 10 miles from Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. They were married six years ago and have one son and one daughter.

For the past 11 years, Rim and Sros have earned a living by working in a garment factory. However, they don't make enough to pay for home repairs, which they desperately need. To build a fence and bathroom in their home, Rim is requesting a loan of $1,000 U.S. dollars.

loans.use: To build a fence and bathroom in a family home

loans.name: Benkadi 4 (L’Entente Est Une Bonne Chose Group

texts.fr:
The women in the Benkadi 4 group are married and, on average, are 23 years old and have four children. They live in polygamous families with their husbands, their husbands’ other wives, and their children in the village of Sikouna 2, in the subprefecture of Fana (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali). Their business consists of selling charcoal, which they buy in neighboring villages from men who are specialized in producing charcoal. They have a place to store the charcoal in front of their family homes and generally sell it retail to a diverse clientele (men and women) and wholesale to people who have market stands in big cities like Ségou Fana and Bamako. Brought together by the fact that they are in the same trade, live in the same village and are each experienced in business, the members of the group were faced with a lack of capital. After much discussion, they decided to join Soro Yiriwaso, from which they are receiving their first group loan. With this loan, they intend to buy an average of 15 bags of charcoal each (1,000 CFA francs per bag). Each bag will then be sold for 1,500 CFA francs, generating a weekly profit of 7,500 CFA francs. This profit will help them pay off the interest on the loan and meet their families’ needs and will above all help them to develop their business.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Les membres du groupe Benkadi 4 sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’age de 23 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans de familles polygames avec leurs maris, coépouses et enfants dans le village de Sikouna 2, sous préfecture de Fana (Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali). L’activité principale de ce groupe de femmes est la vente du charbon. Elles s’approvisionnent dans les villages environnants auprès des hommes spécialisés dans la production du charbon de bois. Elles disposent d’un lieu de stockage devant leurs concessions conjugales et vendent généralement le charbon de bois en détail à une clientèle variée (femmes et hommes) et en gros aux forains venant des grandes villes comme Ségou Fana et Bamako. Unies par des liens professionnels, de voisinage, et disposant d’une grande expérience dans les activités économiques, les membres du groupe étaient confrontés à un problème de fonds de commerce. Après réflexion, elles décidèrent d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur premier prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Avec le prêt, elles comptent acheter chacune 15 sacs de charbon de bois (1.000 FCFA par sac) pour les revendre à 1.500 FCFA l’unité, soit un bénéfice de 7.500 FCFA par semaine, qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux besoins de la famille et surtout renforcer leurs activités.

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal and various items

loans.name: Hongchhay

texts.en:
Hongchhay N., 29, and his wife, Sokha Lai, 27, live in a village near Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. They were married seven years ago and have three sons, one of whom is already in school.

To support his family, Hongchhay sells bricks. He buys them from a kiln in his village and resells them at a construction site in Pnom Penh. Unfortunately, the truck Hongchhay uses to drive the bricks recently broke down and he can't afford the repairs, so he's unable to work. To purchase the parts he needs, Hongchhay is requesting a loan of $1,000 U.S. dollars.

loans.use: To repair a truck needed for a brick-selling business

loans.name: Vorn

texts.en:
Vorn Y., 59, is a mother of five living in an island in the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from the capitol city of Phnom Penh. She is married to Ou Kot, 63, a farmer.

For the past two decades, Vorn has earned a living by weaving silk, a skill that she learned from a relative. One of her sons also weaves silk. They sell their finished product to a middle man in the village, who then peddles it in Phnom Penh's markets. To expand her business, Vorn is requesting a loan of $400 U.S. dollars to buy more raw silk.

loans.use: To buy silk for a family weaving business

loans.name: Félicité

texts.fr:
Born on July 10, 1972 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Ms. Félicité V. is married and the mother of three. She sells basic provisions, namely pasta, beverages, milk, rice, etc. She also sells food and has a small phone center, too. She buys goods in Tokpa, and sometimes in Lomé in TOGO, then markets them in a shop located in her home in the Sènadé district. She is on her third loan with ALIDE and is one of the best recipients of our institution.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Née le 10 Juillet 1972 à Cotonou, la capitale économique du BENIN, dame V. Félicité est mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle vend des produits de première nécessité à savoir les pâtes alimentaires,les boissons,du lait, du riz, etc. Elle vend aussi de la nourriture et possède également un petit télé-centre. Elle achète ses marchandises à Tokpa et quelques fois à Lomé au TOGO puis les commercialise dans une boutique sise à son domicile au quartier Sènadé. Elle est à son troisième prêt à ALIDé et fait partie des meilleures bénéficiaires de notre institution.

loans.use: To buy four 50-kg sacks of ordinary rice, two sacks of perfumed rice, some sacks of beans, and various types of liqueurs

loans.name: Joseph

texts.fr:
Mr. Joseph B. was born in Akpro-Missérété, in the county of l'Ouémé, in the southwest of Benin. He is 38 years old. He is married and the father of four children, who are all in school and in his care. A teacher by profession, he also has a shop in which he markets spare parts for four-stroke motorbikes called “Djènannan”, in comparison to a rare pearl. His shop is situated in the Akpakpa-Dodomè district, and its location enables him to realize considerable sales figures each day. Joseph B. is on his third loan and always honors the due-dates of the payments associated with his loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Monsieur B. Joseph est né à Akpro-Missérété dans le département de l'Ouémé au sud ouest du Bénin. Il est âgé de 38 ans. B. Joseph est marié et père de 4 enfants tous scolarisés dont il a la charge. Instituteur de profession, il possède également une boutique dans laquelle il commercialise les pièces de rechanges de moto quatre temps appelées "Djènannan" en comparaison à une perle rare. Sa boutique est située au quartier Akpakpa-Dodomè. La situation géographique de sa boutique lui permet de réaliser un chiffre d'affaire journalier considérable. B. Joseph est à son troisième crédit et a toujours bien respecté les échéanciers de remboursement liés à son crédit.

loans.use: Tp buy spare parts for four-stroke motorbikes

loans.name: Deme (Soutien Mutuel). Group

texts.fr:
The nine women in the Deme (Mutual Support) group are married and, on average, are 20 years old and have three children. They live in polygamous families with their husbands, their husbands’ other wives, and their children in the village of Sikouna 2 (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali). Their business consists of selling charcoal, which they buy from farmers who have licenses to cut down trees and produce charcoal. They have a place to store the charcoal in their family homes and generally sell it retail to a diverse clientele (men and women) and wholesale to people who have market stands in big cities like Ségou Fana and Bamako. Brought together by the fact that they are in the same trade, live in the same village and are each experienced in business, the members of the group decided that in order to generate additional income, they would join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, from which they are receiving their first group loan. With this loan, they intend to buy an average of 25 bags of charcoal each (1,000 CFA francs per bag). Each bag will then be sold for 1,500 CFA francs, generating a weekly profit of 12,500 CFA francs. This profit will help pay off the interest on the loan and will above all help them to develop their business. Please note that Alimate Diakité is not in the group photo, as she was helping a woman in labor at the community health center in Marka Coungo at the time it was taken.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Les 9 femmes du groupe Deme (Soutien mutuel) sont mariées avec une moyenne d’age de 20 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles polygames avec leurs maris, coépouses et enfants dans le village de Sikouna 2 (Région de Koulikoro République du Mali). L’activité principale de ce groupe de femmes est la vente du charbon de bois, qu’elles achètent avec les paysans qui détiennent des permis de coupe de bois et de fabrication de charbon. Elles disposent d’un lieu de stockage dans la concession conjugale et vendent généralement le charbon de bois en détail à une clientèle variée (femmes et hommes) et en gros aux forains venant des grandes villes comme Ségou Fana et Bamako. Unies par des liens professionnels, de voisinage et très expérimentées dans les activités économiques, les membres du groupe, afin de trouver les ressources complémentaires, ont décidés d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur premier prêt de groupe. Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter chacune en moyenne 25 sacs de charbon (1.000 FCFA par sac). Chaque sac est revendu à 1.500 FCFA, soit un bénéfice hebdomadaire de 12.500 FCFA. Ce bénéfice servira à payer les intérêts du prêt et surtout à renforcer l’activité. Il est à noter que la nommée ALIMATA D. ne se trouve pas sur la photo de groupe. En effet, elle était en train d’assister une femme en travail au centre de santé communautaire de Marka Coungo.

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal and various items

loans.name: Ndeye Coumba

texts.fr:
Ndeye Coumba F. is a married woman and mother of six children. She lives in the Cité Senghor quarter of Thiès and sells seasonal fruits with help from the IMCEC branch located in Thiès. She has taken out small loans before that she was able to repay on time. She is requesting this loan so she can increase her revenue.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

NDEYE COUMBA F. EST UNE FEMME MARIEE ET MERE DE SIX ENFANTS .ELLE HABITE AU QUARTIER CITE SENGHOR ET VENDS DES FRUITS DE SAISON A COTE DE LA DIRECTION DE IMCEC DE THIES .ELLE A EU A BENEFICIER DE PETITES SOMMES QU ELLE A PU REMBOURSER DANS LES DELAIS. C EST DANS LE BUT D AMELIORER SES REVENUS QU ELLE SOLLICITE CE PRET.

loans.use: Purchase and selling of fruits at retail

loans.name: Djantoyerela (La Prudence Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Djantoyerela group are married women who, on average, are 40 years old and have five children. They live in extended families with their husbands, their in-laws, their husbands’ other wives, and their children in the village of Djinina, in the Fana subprefecture (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali). The members of the Djantoyerela group sell grains, Shea almonds and candy. They came together because they are in the same line of business and all live in the same village. The Djantoyerela group is on its eighth group loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, and all of its previous loans were repaid in full. They buy their products in neighboring villages (Marka Coungo, Tinkole and Santiguila), which allows them to keep a sufficient supply. These products are sold as is or are turned into flour to make “farou farou,” a local cake adored by children. For the part of their business that consists of processing Shea almonds, a portion of the loan will be used to pay other women for the almonds. They will sell their products in the villages named above. Each member of the group is involved in at least two different parts of the business and has a great ability to adapt to economic hardships. They hope to earn an average profit of 17,500 CFA francs per month.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Les membres du groupe Djantoyerela sont des femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’age de 40 ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles élargies avec leurs maris, les beaux parents, les coépouses et les enfants dans le village de Djinina, sous préfecture de Fana (Région de Koulikoro République du Mali). Les membres du groupe Djantoyerela font le commerce de céréales et d’amendes de karité et la vente des friandises. Elles se sont connues parce qu’elles font les mêmes activités et vivent dans le même village. Le groupe Djantoyerela est à sont huitième prêt de groupe avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. Elles s’approvisionnent dans les villages voisins (Marka Coungo, Tinkole ou Santiguila) et constituent ainsi un stock suffisant. Ce stock est soit vendu en l’état ou transformé en poudre pour faire le fourou fourou (gâteau local) très prisé par les enfants. Pour l’activité de transformation des amendes de karité, une partie du prêt est utilisée pour payer les amendes auprès d’autres femmes. Les ventes sont effectuées dans les localités ci-dessus citées. Comme on le constate elles mènent chacune au minimum deux activités et disposent d’une grande capacité d’adaptation à la réalité économique. Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 17.500 FCFA par mois.

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Mohamed's Group

texts.en:
Mohamed K. (left), born in Makale, 35 years old, and married with 3 children. He works for the military and engages in agricultural activities. He will use his share of the loan to buy seeds and expand his farm.

Next to him is Abu S.. He was born in Port Loko 24 years ago. He is married with 2 children. He will use his loan to expand his food business.

Foday T. (second to right) is 34 years old and was born in  Pujenhun. He is married with 4 children.  Foday`s wife sells cooked rice, and Foday will use his loan to expand his wife's business. Like his colleagues, Foday will be repaying his loan out of his monthly military salary.

Borbor S. (right) is 25 years old, born in Kamabai. He currently works in Makeni with the military. Borbor will use his loan to get started in farming, a long-time dream of his,

These men are requesting a loan of Le 3,600,000.00 to improve their incomes and better provide for their families.

loans.use: To buy seed rice for farming, and expand their different businesses.

loans.name: Djekafo (Soyons Ensemble Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Djekafo group are married with an average age of 19 years and have 2 children amongst themselves. They live in traditional families with their husbands, their parents-in-law, and their children in the village of Sikouna 1 in the sous-prefecture of Fana, in the Koulikoro Region of Mali. The women have specialized in the business of consumer products such as soap, peanuts, fresh milk, and plastic cooking utensils (buckets, kettles, plates), etc. Having ties to one another due to proximity, alliances, and friendship, the women in the group have taken out their first united loan (group loan) with Soro Yiriwaso. They get their stock from various towns (Bamako, Ségou, etc.) by buying from wholesalers. They sell their goods in Sikouna 1 at home as well as in the markets of surrounding villages. The client base is made up of women from the villages and a few men. In the future, they hope to become wholesalers and serve the neighboring villages.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Les membres du groupe Djekafo sont mariées avec une moyenne d’age de 19 ans et 2 enfants .Elles vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, les beaux parents et les enfants dans le village de Sikouna 1 sous préfecture de Fana (Région de Koulikoro République du Mali). Elles se sont spécialisées dans le commerce des articles de consommation courante comme le savon, l’arachide, le lait frais et les ustensiles de cuisine en plastiques (seaux bouilloires assiettes) etc. Liées par des relations de voisinage, d’alliances et d’amitié, les femmes du groupe sont à leur premier prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe) avec Soro Yiriwaso. Elles s’approvisionnement dans diverses localités (Bamako, Ségou etc…) auprès de grossistes. Les ventes sont effectuées sur place à Sikouna 1 à domicile et dans les marchés des villages environnants. La clientèle est composée de femmes venant des villages et quelques hommes. Dans le futur, elles envisagent devenir des grossistes et servir l’ensemble des villages voisins.

loans.use: Purchase of buckets, plastic cups, and other various items

loans.name: Djiguiseme (Soutien Group

texts.fr:
The four women of the Djiguiseme group are married with an average age of 30 years and have three children amongst themselves. They live in polygamous families with their husbands, co-wives, and children in the village of Konobougou in the Baroueli prefecture, which is in the Ségou Region of Mali. The women work in catering, but more specifically in the production of non-alcoholic beverages such as juices made from wild fruits, flavored powdered juices, etc. The members of this group are linked by ties of work relationships and personal alliances. Having trust in one another, these women decided to take out their first loan from the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. In order to keep their business stocked, they shop in the Konbougou market for raw materials such as wild fruits, powdered juice, packs of small plastic bags, dried hibiscus leaves, ginger, coloring, sugar, etc. The beverages are made (with a recognized skill), put into bags, and refrigerated before being sold at the Konobougou market, either by openly displaying the products in front of them, or by walking up to potential customers. The women each expect to make, on average, 7500 CFA (about $18) a month, which they hope to use to bolster their business.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Les quatre femmes du groupe Djiguiseme sont mariés avec une moyenne d’age de 30 ans 3 enfants et vivent dans des familles polygames très généralement avec leurs maris, des coépouses, et les enfants dans le village de Konobougou préfecture de Baroueli. (Région de Ségou République du Mali). Elles travaillent essentiellement dans le domaine de la restauration et surtout la fabrication de boissons locales non alcoolisées (jus de fruits sauvages, jus en poudre aromatisé etc ). Les membres de ce groupe sont beaucoup unis par des liens de travail et d’alliances .Se faisant mutuellement confiance ces femmes ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur premier prêt. Pour mener à bien leurs activités, elles s’approvisionnent dans le marché de Konbougou en matières premières (les fruits sauvages les jus en poudre, les paquets de sachets plastiques, du dah, du zinzimbre, des colorants et du sucre, etc). Les boissons sont fabriqués (avec une technicité reconnue), mis en sachet et rafraîchies avant la vente au marché de Konobougou (sur des étales ou de façon ambulante). Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 7.500FCFAavec lequel elles envisagent d’investir essentiellement dans leurs activités.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials for beverages

loans.name: El Renacer Group

texts.en:
Argentina C. is a 36-year-old woman who lives with her husband and four children (ages 11, 14, 17, and 18) in a small community called Quisquella Verde in the eastern province of Hato Mayor in the Dominican Republic. She began a small business selling undergarments earlier this year and continues to increase her inventory with each loan. Argentina travels by bus from town to town selling her products to people in the small communities in the countryside as many of these rural people do not have the means to travel to town to do their shopping. She has started this business so that she can provide her children with a good education and a comfortable home. In Argentina’s free time, she enjoys going to church and spending time with her family.

Argentina is the leader of the 5-person micro-bank group, Renacer. In English, this means ´rebirth`. These unique Dominican entrepreneurs have united in solidarity, allowing them to access funding that they would never be able to receive on their own.

On behalf of Argentina, the Renacer group, and the entire team here at Esperanza International, we thank you for your support of this micro-loan!

loans.use: To buy various undergarments for re-sale

loans.name: Djiguitougou (Assurance). Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Djiguitougou group are married, with an average age of 40 years, and they have 6 children amongst themselves. They live in Fana-coura, one of the neighborhoods of the city of Fana, in the Koulikoro Region of Mali, and they have polygamous families with husbands, co-wives, and children. They make non-alcoholic beverages (fruit juices, powdered juice, juice made from dah (dried hibiscus leaves), and juice made with ginger). Due to a mutual trust for one another, and being united by work relationships and friendship, the four women of the Djiguitougou group have been in collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso for two years. The women have taken out four loans which they have repaid in full. They stock up on raw materials at the central market in Fana (wild fruits, powdered juice, packs of small plastic bags, dah (dried hibiscus leaves), ginger, colorings, and flavorings). The juices are made daily, generally at night, put into bags, and refrigerated before being sold in the morning at the market, in the schools, or at the houses of loyal and regular customers. The women expect to each make about 15,000 CFA (about $36) monthly, with which they hope to bolster their business.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Les membres du groupe Djiguitougou sont mariés avec une moyenne d’age de 40 ans 6 enfants et vivent à Fana coura un des quartiers de la ville de Fana (Région de Koulikoro République du Mali) dans des familles polygames avec maris, coépouses et enfants . Elles font essentiellement la fabrication de boissons locales non alcoolisées (Jus de fruits sauvages, jus en poudre, jus de dah et de zinzimbre etc). Se faisant confiance et unies par des liens de travail et d’amitié, les quatre femmes du groupe Djiguitougou ont deux ans de collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso. Elles ont bénéficié de quatre prêts tous remboursés. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Fana en matières premières (les fruits sauvages, les jus en poudre, les paquets de sachets plastiques, le dah, le zinzimbre, les colorants et les aromes). Les jus sont fabriqués quotidiennement généralement le soir, mis en sachet et réfrigérés avant la vente le matin au marché, dans les écoles ou à la maison à une clientèle fidèle et régulière. Elles comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.000FCFA avec lequel elles envisagent investir essentiellement dans leurs activités.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials for beverages; purchase of incense

loans.name: Adugbe

texts.en:
Adugbe A. is a fishmonger. She is a widow with 4 children. Demand for her fish is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Vladislava

texts.en:
Vladislava is married with two children. She lives in Zaporozhye, where she sells clothing in the Yubileinyi market. She has been in this trade for ten years. Presently, she has about $3000 in inventory. Her gross income is about $1000.

Vladislava has an active entrepreneurial mind that is always looking for the next big opportunity. Her business is profitable and stable, but she would like to press on and expand it even more. Today Vladislava is requesting a loan of 4500 Grivnas to increase her clothing stock and meet the growing demands of the summer season. She is hoping to open a second vending facility in the future.

loans.use: Expand clothing business to meet summer demands

loans.name: Oksana

texts.en:
Oksana is married. She is an entrepreneur from Zaporozhye where she sells clothing in the busy Yubileinyi market. She has been in this business for 10 years. Currently, Oksana has about $2400. Her gross income is about $2400.

Oksana is requesting a 5000 Grivna loan to purchase seasonal clothing in bulk. She is achievement-oriented and has confidence in her abilities and powers. We believe these crucial characteristics that Oksana possesses will secure further growth of her trade and prompt loan repayment.

loans.use: To increase sales stock

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris A. is a seamstress who is specialized in the sewing of school uniforms. She is a single parent with 3 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to buy more fabrics for the sewing of school uniforms.

loans.use: to buy more fabrics for the sewing of school uniforms

loans.name: Foday's Group

texts.en:
This group is request a loan of Le 3,500,000.00. The members are (from right to left): Foday M., Mohamed Koroma, Abu-Bakarr J. and Alfred T..


Foday will give his loan to his wife who is sells clothes(gara lappers) so she can improve her business. Foday`s plan is to see his wife`s business booming as this (together with his monthly salary) can help them a lot in improving the living standard of their family. The two have 4 children.

Mohamed K.`s ambition is to further his education. Though currently working for the army, he will use his loan to pursue his education while still military work.

Abu-Bakarr will use his loan to buy more timber and other essential  working materials he uses in making furniture to sell. Abu-Bakarr is a skilled carpenter working with the army.

 33-year-old Alfred T., will buy more local produce to sell. The proceeds he gets from his sales add to his small monthly salary from the military.

loans.use: To buy cement, timber, and other working materials, and for education

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina has operated her small retail business at the busy Yubileinyi market in Zaporozhye for ten years. Zaporozhye is located in the south-east of Ukraine. She has learned a lot over the years she’s been in business. She has enjoyed the opportunity to work for herself and her income has been a big help to her. Presently, she has about $5000 in inventory.

Galina has requested a loan that will enable her to buy product in bulk to sell in her kiosk. The ability to purchase in large quantities can save a lot of time, effort and money for her as she can obtain better pricing from her suppliers and make fewer trips to buy inventory. Galina is grateful for the financial support she has received through “Nadiya Ukraine”. We look forward to seeing her business continue to be successful and provide for Galina’s needs.

loans.use: To buy more products

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya has been running her retail business for four years. She started as a small vendor in a store called “Kashtan” (“Chestnut”). The store is located in the central street of her hometown which is very convenient for customers who shop downtown Ordzhonikidze. Natalya sells household chemicals and little necessities that each family can use at home. Presently, she has about $6000 in turnover capital. Her income is about $900 each month.

Natalya would like to keep her income stable and increase her turnover capital which is why she is requesting a loan of 2500 Grivnas to be repaid in two months. We believe consistent demand, outstanding credit history and entrepreneurial enthusiasm will guarantee loan repayment without any delinquencies.

Note: this is a short term “seasonal” loan that will be repaid in 2 months.

loans.use: To re-stock her inventory

loans.name: Alexei

texts.en:
Alexei’s family consists of his wife and four children. Nearly 2 years ago he decided to launch a small venture offering lithography and gravestone technique services--a business he says that was his calling. He was able to rent a small facility in his town which works as his shop and is easily accessible to many customers. Today, Alexei’s business yields $700 a month in income.

Alexei sees a great opportunity for business growth in the future. His expertise in this sphere of business is greatly appreciated by his customers. His desire to assist clients and his entrepreneurial spirit are part of what makes his business successful. Alexei has requested a loan for 5,000 Grivnas to broaden the assortment of equipment he uses in his work so that he will be ready for more complicated orders. He has proven to be a strong and reliable client with “Nadiya Ukraine”. We believe that this loan will be a big help to Alexei as he looks for ways to increase his business activity.

loans.use: To purchase equipment

loans.name: Afi

texts.en:
Afi F. is a fishmonger. She is a single parent whose income is not sufficient for herself and her 5 children. Demand for her processed fish is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Afi is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is a married mom with one daughter. She runs a small business selling leather goods in the local market of Nikolaev called "Sigma-sport". Her business doesn't face much competition as there are very few other businessmen with similar products. Tatyana started this venture about a year ago. However, she has already making about $400 in profit each month.

Tatyana is seeking a loan of 5000 Grivnas for 8 months. She is hoping to see her business grow further and expand even more. On the personal level she would like to invest a part of profits generated in remodeling of her apartment which has been her dream for awhile. Tatyana is known as an entrepreneur of integrity and determination. We believe her commitment to her venture and personal characteristics will help her repay the current loan without any problems.

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is married with three sons. She supports the essential needs of her household by running a small business selling household items and clothing merchandise in the busy city market in Berdyansk. Currently, Tatyana has about $3000 of working capital in her business and her income amounts to $2,000.

Tatyana is very patient and polite. Her commitment to good business and her natural friendliness attract many potential clients. A variety of quality products also makes her kiosk a popular stop for passing customers. Tatyana continues to work hard investing her time and efforts in the growth of her business. She has been in this trade for 7 years and her business is continuously expanding. Tatyana is requesting a loan of 2500 Grivnas to purchase assorted merchandise at good wholesale prices. This loan will help to significantly boost Tatyana's revenue and grow her business, further improving the quality of life for her and her family.

Note: this is a short term "seasonal" loan that will be repaid in 2 months.

loans.use: To purchase assorted merchandise

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria W. is a fishmonger. She is a single parent whose income is not sufficient for herself and her 2 children. Demand for her processed fish is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Victoria is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya is married with two children. Five years ago she started her retail business selling clothing and footwear in one of the local markets in Berdyansk. High sales rates, loyal customers, and a convenient location for her vending kiosk all contributed to good performance. Natalya admits lending services from "Nadiya Ukraine" have benefited her a lot in this area of business. 

Today, Natalya has about $2400 of working capital. She has proven to be a hard-working, dedicated entrepreneur and runs her business with integrity and innovation. She doesn't hesitate when taking risks, which has helped her to succeed despite serious competition in the market. Natalya is requesting a loan of 2500 Grivnas to purchase merchandise at wholesale prices to sell in her vending location. This loan will help her expand her business and will have a positive impact on her trade profitability, helping to further improve the economic and social situation of her family.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice K. is a fishmonger. She is married, but her husband's income as a fisherman is not sufficient for Beatrice and her 6 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Beatrice is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Sorie's Group

texts.en:
This group consists of (from left to right): Sorie D., Abu-Bakarr K. and John Sahr F.. These men work for the military and are also engaged in either agriculture or business. They are requesting a loan of Le 2,600,000.00. This will be repaid through their monthly military salaries.

Sorie D., 33, is married with 4 children. He will use his loan to invest in business. Abu-Bakarr will invest his in agriculture. He is age 34, born in Banta-Gbenti. He is married with 2 children. And John will invest his loan in business too. He sells food stuffs and has 5 years of experience in the business. John was born in Kailahun District 32 years ago. He is married with 3 children.

loans.use: To expand existing businesses

loans.name: German

texts.es:
German lives together with his parents in “Brazil Street”, in the neighborhood of Ballivian in the city of El Alto.

German sells spare parts; he buys cars which have had an accident, dismantles them and later on sells the spare parts at the main market of El Alto. The loan he will receive he will use it to buy more cars and sell spare parts.

It is the first loan he takes with Impro and the analysis that was done qualifies him to obtain the credit.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

German vive en la calle Brasil de la zona Ballivián en la ciudad de El Alto. Vive en la casa de sus padres. Trabaja en la comercialización de chatarra, la cual consiste en la compra de vehículos siniestrados (volcados, chocados) los cuales los desmantela y los vende como repuestos en la principal feria de la ciudad de El Alto El crédito lo destinará como capital de trabajo, para la compra de más vehículos y poder vender los repuestos y partes que aún están en estado de uso. Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada la califica para otorgarle el préstamo.

loans.use: To buy more damaged cars and sell spare parts

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama F. is a fishmonger. She is married, but her husband's income as a soldier is not sufficient for Ama and her 1 child. Demand for her processed fish is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Ama is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Anastacia

texts.es:
Anastacia and her husband have 6 children. Love has always united them and given them strength to confront difficult moments together. As a help to support her home and supplement her husband’s income, Anastacia opened a convenience store in their home, with a little bit of merchandise to start, but is has been growing and she has noted how useful her store has been to her neighbors. Her neighbors see her as a just person, one who doesn’t take advantage of the needs of others and she always charges a fair price. For this reason Anastacia has seen her work not only as an economic means but also as a service to her community. Therefore, she is here asking for a loan that will be used to expand her store, she would like to improve the lighting and buy a greater variety of merchandise to meet her customer’s needs. She promises to be faithful and responsible in her payments, as she is an honored and honorable woman.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

Anastacia y su esposo tienen 6 hijos, el amor que siempre los ha unido le ha dado fuerza para afrontar juntos los momentos difíciles. Como una ayuda para el sustento de su hogar y complemento del trabajo de su esposo, Anastacia puso una bodega en su casa, con poca mercadería para comenzar, pero ha ido creciendo la demanda y ella se ha dado cuenta lo útil que su bodega es para sus vecinos, ya que ven en ella una persona justa, que no se aprovecha de su necesidad y siempre les cobra el precio justo. Por esta razón Anastacia ha visto en su trabajo no sólo un medio de ganancia económicas, sino también un servicio a favor de su comunidad.Debido a ello, se presenta aquí solicitando un préstamo que utilizará para la ampliación de su bodega, quiere ambientarla mejor y comprar mayor y variada mercadería para seguir complaciendo a sus clientes. Ella promete ser fiel y responsable en sus pagos, ya que es una mujer honrada y honorable.

loans.use: Expand and remodel her store to better serve her neighbors

loans.name: María

texts.es:
María has been a widow for 13 years. After getting over the pain of losing her life companion, María gained strength and educated and took care of her children by herself. She is dedicated to working the land and after the death of her husband, she had to redouble efforts to take care of living costs. Times have changed; for María, who sees rising prices and costs each day, the loan that she seeks will be used to buy fertilizer for her land. She wishes that her next harvest will be more productive than the previous one, so she can make large profits in the market. She goes through lots of trouble for this endeavor.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

Hace 13 años María quedó viuda, tras sobreponerse de la pena de perder a su compañero de toda la vida, María sacó fuerza y sola supo educar y cuidar de sus 6 hijos. Ella se dedica a los trabajos en el campo, y tuvo que redoblar esfuerzos para suplir los gastos en su casa, luego de la muerte de su esposo, es un trabajo duro, pero tuvo que hacerlo. Los tiempos han cambiado, y también para María que ve como los precios de lo que ella necesita a diario suben cada día, el préstamo que solicita hoy es para la compra de abonos y fertilizantes, ella desea que su próxima cosecha sea más productiva que la anterior, para obtener mayores ganancias en el mercado, y eso se puede lograr con esmero.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to cultivate her land

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace O. is a fishmonger. She is married, but her husband's income as a fisherman is not sufficient for her and her 3 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Grace is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary has been trading in the market for the past 10 years. She is divorced, with two children. Mary enjoys selling and she is motivated to work hard because she dreams of a better future for her children. She trades in onion, ginger, and eggs on top of a table. She would like a loan of $975 to add rice, sugar and vegetable oil to her inventory of goods to increase her income. She hopes to use part of her profits to support her children in school. Mary belongs to the community group called Living Faith Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for the repayment of each others' loans through pledge.

loans.use: To add rice, sugar ,and vegetable oil to her inventory of foodstuffs for sale at the market

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca K. produces ‘tie and dye’ fabric for sale. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Rebecca and her 1 child. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Rebecca is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul is 29 years old and married with one child. He has supported his family as a photographer for the past 10 years. He owns a photography shop where his clients pose for their photographs. He also goes to parties and concerts to take photos of his clients. Paul would like a loan of $975 to purchase tools and materials like a camera, flash, video camera etc. to expand his business. His goal is to earn extra income and improve the welfare of his family. Paul belongs to the community group called Living Faith Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee the repayment of their loans through pledge.

loans.use: To buy tools and materials like a camera, flash, and video camera for his photography business

loans.name: Lumor

texts.en: Lumor is 36 years old and single. He has been a general photographer for 10 years and loves his work. He also does glass cutting and shoots video. Lumor owns a photography and video shop where his clients pose for their photographs. He also goes to parties and concerts to take photos of his clients. He requests a loan of $975 to buy additional tools and materials like a new camera, flash, video camera, glass, and other materials to expand his studio. Lumor belongs to the community group called Living Faith Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee the repayment of their loans through pledge.

loans.use: To buy additional cameras and materials for his photography business

loans.name: Alimamy B.'s Group

texts.en:
This group consists of: (from right to left): Alimamy B. K., Sinneh C., Alie K. and George H..

Alimamy was born in Makeni. He is now 38, married with 4 children. Alimamy is currently engaged in building a house, and will use his loan to complete the building process. Though he is an army officer, his monthly salary cannot buy him the materials he needs.

Sinneh, will use the loan to help him increase his current business. He skilfully combines his military work with petty-trading within the barracks. Sinneh is married with 2 children. He is 38 and was born in 4 Mile.

Alie was born in Mile 91. He is 34, married with 3 children. He will give his loan to his wife who sells a variety of items like pastes, bars of soap, cigarettes, matches etc. This will help her expand her business.

George H., 34, will use his loan to develop his farm. 

These soldiers are requesting a loan of Le 3,500,000.00 in total. The loan will be repaid out of their monthly military salaries.

loans.use: To buy building materials.

loans.name: Bismarck

texts.en: Bismarck is 33 years old, married, and has one child. He has been a dealer in used refrigerators and parts for the past 10 years. He also repairs refrigerators for his customers. Bismark buys supplies from importers at wholesale prices and sells them to his customers at retail prices. Used refrigerators are in high demand for those who cannot afford to buy a new one. Bismark requests a loan of $975 so he can purchase additional refrigerators and parts. He belongs to the community group called Evergreen Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee the repayment of their loans through pledge.
