loans.use: To procure additional refrigerators and parts

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Djiguiya (Espoir Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Djiguiya group are married with an average age of 37 and seven children. They live in traditional families with their husbands, parents-in-law and children in the village of Konobougou in the Baroueli prefecture, located in Mali’s Ségou region. They specialize in selling food spices and traditional utensils for cooking, etc. The relationship among the women of the Djiguiya group is one of neighborhood bonds and friendship. They are on their third solidarity loan from Soro Yiriwaso and all previous loans were repaid without problem. They get their supplies from a variety of sources depending on the item, but for utensils, they mainly buy their stock from local people in the surrounding villages. For food spices, they go to Bamako or Ségou. Sales take place in Konobougou, either at home or in the market, especially on market days when customers are itinerant merchants from neighboring towns and villages. With this loan, the members of the Djiguiya group expect to make a monthly profit of CFA 20,000, which they will use to pay the loan interest and invest the remainder in their respective businesses.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Les membres du groupe Djiguiya sont mariés avec une moyenne d’age de 37 ans et 7 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, les beaux parents et les enfants dans le village de Konobougou préfecture de Baroueli (Région de Ségou République du Mali). Elles se sont spécialisées dans le commerce de condiments alimentaires et des ustensiles traditionnels de cuisine etc. Les femmes du groupe Djiguiya ont une relation de voisinage d’alliances et d’amitié. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire avec Soro Yiriwaso et les précédents ont été remboursés sans difficulté. Les sources d’approvisionnement sont diverses et variées suivant les articles mais pour les ustensiles c’est essentiellement dans les villages environnants avec les paysans qu’elles se ravitaillent. Pour les condiments alimentaires, elles le font à Bamako ou à Ségou. Les ventes se font sur place à Konobougou à domicile ou au marché surtout les jours de foire à une clientèle composée de forains venant des villes et villages voisins. Avec ce prêt les membres du groupe Djiguiya comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20.000 FCFA qu’elles utiliseront pour payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans leurs activités respectives.

loans.use: To buy utensils and miscellaneous items

loans.name: Mujeres Decidida De Restauracion Group

texts.en: Maria M. is the leader of her Bank of Hope, Mujeres Decidida D. Restauracion ("Women Determined for Restoration").  She is the mother of four, aged 24, 26, 28, and 30, and has used her Esperanza loan to start her craft-selling business.  Her future ambitions incluD. expanding her business and providing a comfortable life for her grandchildren.

loans.use: Manualidades Nazareno (Christian crafts)

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua M. sells oil, tomatoes, pepper, and other food items. She is married, but her husband's income as a fisherman is not sufficient for Efua and her 5 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Efua is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Djiguiseme 2 (Soutien Group

texts.fr:
The women in the Djiguiseme group are mostly married with an average age of 30 and four children each. They live in traditional families with their husbands, co-wives and children in the village of Konobougou in the Baroueli prefecture (in Mali’s Ségou region). They run a business mainly selling food spices and traditional beauty products (incense, etc.). Brought together through neighborhood ties and friendship, they have been working with Soro Yiriwaso for one year and are on their third group loan. All previous loans were repaid without problem. They stock up on raw materials in Konobougou on market days, buying spices from wholesalers from Ségou and incense primarily from wholesalers from Bamako. They sell at the same market in Konobougou, either at stalls or by walking around, and do this throughout the year. Their customers are women who sell to neighboring villages or women from Konobougou. The group plans to buy 15 kg of spices (pepper, abutilon, laurel, etc.) at CFA 2,000/kg to sell at CFA 2,500/kg, hence a weekly profit of CFA 7,500, and incense ingredients (2 kg of magnonkisèni, 5 kg of gueni, and 4 bottles of perfume) at a cost of CFA 25,000, which would yield a profit of CFA 30,000 per month. Each member of the group hopes to make a monthly profit of CFA 30,000 with which they will pay the loan interest and increase their capital.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Les femmes du groupe Djiguiseme sont à majorité mariées avec une moyenne d’age de 30 ans et 4 enfants .Elles vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, coépouses et enfants dans le village de Konobougou préfecture de Baroueli (Région de Ségou République du Mali) Elles font essentiellement le commerce de : condiments alimentaires et des produits de beauté traditionnelles (encenses etc.) Unies par des liens de voisinage et d’amitié elles collaborent avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis une année et sont à leur troisième prêt de groupe. Tous les précédents ont été remboursés sans difficulté. Elles se ravitaillent en matières premières les jours de foire sur place à Konobougou auprès des grossistes venant de Ségou pour les condiments alimentaires et pour l’encense c’est essentiellement avec les Bamakois. Elles effectuent leurs ventes dans le marché (de la même localité Konobougou) sur des étales, de façon ambulante et cela durant toute l’année. La clientèle est constituée de femmes revendeuses des villages environnants et de certaines femmes de Konobougou Le groupe compte acheter 15kilogrammes d’épices (poivre, fièfiè, laurier etc.)à 2000FCFA le kg et vendus à 2500FCFA soit un bénéfice hebdomadaire de 7500fca et pour l’encense (2 kg de magnonkisèni, 5 kg de gueni, 4 bouteilles de parfums soit) une dépense de 25000FCFA vous permet de réaliser un bénéfice de 30 000FCFA par mois. Chaque membre du groupe espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30.000CFAavec lequel elles vont payer les intérêts du prêt et augmenter leurs capitaux.

loans.use: To buy raw materials and miscellaneous items

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth M. is a fishmonger. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Elizabeth and her 3 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Elizabth is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Mukarwego's Group

texts.en:
Mukarwego B. was born in 1968 in Kimisagara. She is a married woman with seven children and two orphans under her charge. She sells crops. She began her business in 1999 with 5000RWF as capital. She currently has a capital of 200,000RWF. She has seven children in secondary school and pays for the school fees from income generated by her business. She has also been able to build their own shelter.

She is requesting a loan to increase her business and expects to extend it by selling honey from Umutara producers.

loans.use: Increase and extend her business by adding honey

loans.name: Víctor

texts.es:
Victor is 43 years old and he is married. His wife, Natividad, is a very hardworking and understanding woman. Together, hand in hand, they sustain their household and pay for the education of their children.

Victor works in public transportation. Where he lives the three-wheeler light vans are often used for public transportation and that is why he decided to buy one and become a driver. Time has passed by and Victor would like to try other activities, one day he would like to open a small workshop to repair motorcycles.

He now requests a loan to buy another three-wheeler light van to provide work to a young man who works with him as a driver and he will keep on driving the three-wheeler he already owns. Victor wants to ask you to trust in him, he believes that he is a hard working and honest person. He gives his word that he will pay back the money within the agreed loan term.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

Víctor tiene 43 años, es casado, su esposa, Natividad es una mujer muy compresiva y trabajadora con la que mano a mano y diariamente soportan la educación de sus hijos y el sustento de su hogar.

El trabajo de Víctor es el transporte de pasajeros, en la zona donde él vive es muy usado el motocarro para el traslado urbano, y él optó por comprarse uno y ser él mismo el chofer. Ha pasado el tiempo y Víctor quiere optar por otras actividades a la par del transporte, él desea poner un pequeño puesto de venta de repuestos para moto.

Él solicita un préstamo para adquirir otro motocarro, y darle trabajo a un muchacho trabajador como chofer, mientras él sigue manejando el otro motocarro. Víctor quiere pedirles que confíen en él, ya que él considera que es una persona trabajadora y honrada, da su palabra de devolver el dinero en el plazo mencionado.

loans.use: To buy another three-wheeler light van to provide work to a young man who works with him as a driver

loans.name: Jackeline

texts.es:
Jackeline is 20 years old and dedicates herself to selling clothes. When she started this job it was like a hobby for her, but now that she is growing and maturing, she has realized that this is a job which has brought her a lot of money, and which has taught her the value of work. She knows that with her young age, she can work even harder to become a prosperous businesswoman in the near future. With the help of some relatives who live in the capital city of Lima, Jackeline continues to acquire very high quality items in all styles and for all ages. Thank God she has the unconditional support of her parents, who encourage her every day to continue with her business for them and for her future. Jacklen has decided to ask you for the amount of money she is asking to borrow, so that she can rent a small place to sell her goods, also allowing her to get more merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva volunteer.

Jackeline tiene 20 años, y se dedica a la venta de ropa, cuando ella inició este oficio era como un pasatiempo para ella, pero ahora que va creciendo y madurando se ha dado cuenta que es un negocia que la ha traído muchas ganancias y le ha enseñado el valor del trabajo, sabe que con su juventud puede esforzarse aún más para ser una próspera empresaria en un futuro cercano.Con la ayuda de unos familiares que viven en Lima, la capital, Jackeline consigue adquirir prendas de muy buena calidad y de variados modelos para todas las edades. Gracias a Dios, ella cuanta con el apoyo incondicional de sus padres, quienes le incentivan a seguir con su trabajo cada día, por ellos y por su futuro, Jackeline decidió recurrir a ustedes para que tengan a bien proporcionarle la cantidad de dinero que pide, en préstamo, para alquilar un pequeño local donde vender sus prendas y así poder adquirir mayor mercadería.

loans.use: Renting a place to sell her clothes.

loans.name: Djiguiya 2 (Soutien) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Djiguiya 2 group are married. Their average age is 30 and they have, on average, 6 children. They live in Sikouna 2, one of the villages of the Fana Sous-prefecture, Republic of Mali, in polygamous families with their husbands, co-spouses, parents-in-law, brothers, sisters, and children.

They are essentially engaged in selling grocery items: bags of powdered milk, packets of pasta, dried and smoked fish, sugar, salt, soap, etc. With confidence in each other and united by ties of work and friendship, these women have decided to collaborate with the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso this year. This is their first loan as a group. They generally procure their merchandise in the big open-air market in Fana or at the Marka Coungo fair, their economic metropolis for the aforementioned items.

They sell on a cash or credit basis, generally retail, at the same fair, under shed roofs, on tables, often even on the ground, or as ambulant salespeople going to village houses. Their clientele is essentially composed of women, children and male heads of families wanting to vary their meals.

With this loan, the women of Djiguiya will purchase 50 packets of pasta, 10 kg of fish, 20 bags of powdered milk, 10 kg of sugar, packets of tea, etc., that is, they will spend 50,000 FCFA, hoping to make a monthly average profit of 15,000 FCFA with which they plan to make payments on the loan, re-invest in their businesses, and contribute to family living expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Djiguiya 2 sont mariés avec une moyenne d’age de 30 ans 6 enfants et vivent à Sikouna 2 un des villages de la sous préfecture de Fana (Région de Koulikoro République du Mali) dans des familles polygames avec leurs maris, des coépouses, les beaux parents, les frères, les soeurs et les enfants.

Elles exercent essentiellement le commerce d’articles divers qui s’apparente à une munie alimentation : sachets de lait en poudre, paquets de pâtes alimentaires le poisson fumé, séché sucre, sel de cuisine savon etc. Se faisant réciproquement confiance et unies par des liens de travail et de d’amitié ces femmes ont décidés de collaborer avec le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année. Elles sont à leur premier prêt de groupe. Elles s’approvisionnent généralement au grand marché de Fana ou à la foire de Marka coungo leur métropole économique pour les articles ci-dessus cités.

Elles effectuent leurs ventes au comptant à crédit généralement en détail dans la même foire sous des hangars sur des étales souvent a même le sol, d’une façon ambulante devant dans les maisons aux villages .La clientèle est essentiellement composée de femmes d’enfants et de pères de famille désirant changer de repas

Avec ce prêt ces femmes du groupe Djiguiya en achetant 50 paquets de pâte alimentaires ,10kg de poissons, 20 sachets de lait en poudre 10 kg de sucre des paquets de thé etc. soit une dépense de 50000FCFA espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15 000FCFA avec lequel elles envisagent payer les intérêts de prêt investir dans leurs activités et contribuer aux dépenses de la famille. essentiellement dans leurs activités.

loans.use:
Purchase of various goods for re-sale

Achat de divers articles

loans.name: Edgar

texts.es:
Edgar is 40 years old with three children. Because of irreparable differences, he had to end his marriage and move away from his children, but although he doesn’t live with them, he continues to dedicate his efforts to their future. Without doubt he tells them to be good and responsible every time they are near him. Years ago, Edgar started his work as a motorcycle taxi driver, and today after a lot of work, he is the proud owner of his own motorcycle taxi. At the same time, he dedicates himself to raising corn, yucca, and bananas, products which he takes to sell at the market in his area. Edgar’s vehicle has presented mechanical faults and the loan which he is asking you for is to buy the parts and pay the mechanic in charge of the repairs. This father needs your support to continue in his daily work, which is his sustenance.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva volunteer.

Edgar tiene 40 años y 3 hijos, por diferencias irreparables tuvo que separarse de su pareja y alejarse de sus hijos, pero a pesar que no vive con ellos, él sigue dedicando su esfuerzo para el futuro de ellos, no duda en aconsejarles, cada vez que los tiene cerca, que sean buenos y responsables.Años atrás el señor Edgar empezó su trabajo como chofer de motocarro para el trasporte de pasajeros, hoy después de mucho es fuerzo ya es propietario de su propio motocarro y se dedica paralelamente al cultivo de maíz, yuca y plátano principalmente, productos que lleva a vender al mercado de su zona.El vehículo de Edgar ha presentado fallas mecánicas y el préstamo que él les pide es para la compra de repuestos y el pago al mecánico que se encargará de la compostura. Este padre, necesita de tu apoyo para continuar en su diaria labor, cual es su sustento.

loans.use: Purchase of parts and payment for the repairs of his motorcycle taxi.

loans.name: Eloy

texts.es:
Eloy started working as a motorcycle taxi driver at a very early age. When he saw the needs of his parents and siblings, he knew that he could help with his strength and his work. After all these years, he’s now 27, and he has become one of the main supporters of his family now that his parents are losing their strength and cannot work as hard as they used to. Because of this, Eloy knows that the fruits of his labor are not only for him to spend, but also for his parents’ retirement. He is also single and hopes with his heart to keep working so that he can support what will eventually be his own family. Because of his starting as a driver, he now has his own motorcycle taxi, which is the reason he is asking for this loan, to repair the mechanical faults of his vehicle and continue with his work.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva volunteer.

Eloy empezó a trabajar desde muy temprana edad, como chofer de motocarro, al ver la necesidad de sus padres y hermanos, supo que él podía ayudar con su trabajo y esfuerzo. Luego de tantos años, él tiene ya 27, se ha convertido en uno de los sustentos primordiales de su casa, ya que la fuerza de sus padres se van desvaneciendo y no pueden dedicarse al trabajo con tanta fuerza como lo hacían antes, por ello Eloy sabe que las ganancias de su trabajo no son sólo para sus gastos personales, sino también para la vejez de sus padres. Él es soltero aún y guarda en su corazón seguir trabajando por el sustento de lo que será su propia familia. A pesar que empezó como chofer, ahora él tiene su propio motocarro, que es el motivo por el que presenta esta solicitud de préstamo, para reparar las fallas mecánicas que ha presentado su vehículo y poder continuar con su trabajo.

loans.use: Repairing the mechanical errors in his motorcycle taxi.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah M. buys fish in large quantities for sale in smaller and affordable quantities. She is married, but her husband's income as a fisherman is not sufficient for Hannah and her 3 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Hannah is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Hugo

texts.es:
Hugo became independent at 20 years old and his energy and enthusiasm led him to work as a mototaxi driver. Now, 9 years later, Hugo is the owner of his own vehicle which he cares for and personally drives. This young man would like to rent a space where he could sell spare parts and lubricants for mototaxis, and he has been saving his money for this. Unfortunately his mototaxi has been having problems and Hugo would like you to help him obtain the loan that he is requesting in order to repair the mototaxi. He does not want to fall behind on his goal of having his own lube center. For now he depends on your support to continue his efforts.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

Hugo se independizó a los 20 años, su ímpetu y entusiasmo lo llevó empezar a trabajar como chofer de un motocarro, hoy luego de 9 años, Hugo ya es dueño de su propio vehículo que cuida y maneja personalmente, el deseo de este joven es alquilar un local donde pueda vender repuestos y lubricantes para motos, y es por ello que ahorra diariamente. Lamentablemente su motocarro está sufriendo desperfectos y Hugo desea que le puedan brindar el préstamo que solicita para poder arreglarlo, él no quiere retroceder con su meta de tener su lubricentro, y por ahora depende de tu apoyo para continuar en su esfuerzo.

loans.use: Repair his mototaxi

loans.name: Faida (Finesse) Group

texts.fr:
The women of the Faida group, on average 25 years old with 5 children, live in extended traditional families with their husbands and children in the village of Konobougou, Baroueli Prefecture, (Region of Ségou, Republic of Mali).

The group sells diverse items: cosmetics, clothing and especially condiments (smoked fish, dried fish, spices, etc.).

They are essentially linked by professional and neighborhood ties, and by ties of friendship.

Group solidarity being strong, the members of Faida group have decided to continue with Soro Yiriwaso which has given them three group loans so far. The previous loans have all been reimbursed correctly.

The group generally stocks up at the end of the month, buying from wholesalers in the big open-air market in Bamako as far as clothing and cosmetics are concerned, getting their fish in Ségou and spices in their own village of Konobougou. They sell their products either out of their homes or at the open-air market, or as ambulant salespeople. The group generally sells on credit to salaried purchasers but also for cash and retail at the market.

The members of Faida group hope that with 30 kg of smoked fish (bought at 1500 FCFA per kilo and sold on credit at 2500 FCFA per kilo) they will make an average monthly profit of 30,000 FCFA which will essentially be re-invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les femmes du groupe Faida, âgées de 25 ans avec 5 enfants en moyenne vivent dans des familles élargies traditionnelles avec leurs époux, et enfants dans le village de Konobougou préfecture de Baroueli (Région de Ségou République du Mali.)

Le groupe fait le commerce d’articles divers : cosmétiques, habillements et surtout les condiments alimentaires (poisson fumé, séché, épices etc.)

Elles sont essentiellement unies par des liens professionnels de voisinage et d’amitié.

La solidarité du groupe ne souffrant d’aucune faille les membres de Faida ont décidé de continuer avec Soro Yiriwaso qui leurs a octroyé trois prêts de groupe .Les précédents ont été remboursés correctement.

L’approvisionnement de ce groupe se fait généralement en fin du mois auprès des grossistes au grand marché de Bamako pour l’habillement et les cosmétiques, Ségou pour les poissons et Konobougou même pour les épices.. Elles viennent revendre leurs articles suivant les cas à la maison soit au marché soit de façon ambulante. Les ventes de ce groupe se font généralement à crédit aux salariés mais aussi au comptant et à détail au niveau du marché.

Les membres du groupe Faida espèrent réaliser avec 30kg de poisson fumé (acheté à1500FCFA l’unité et vendus à crédit à 2500FCFA) réaliser un bénéfice moyen et mensuel de30000FCFA qui servira essentiellement à l’investissement dans l’activité.

loans.use:
Purchase of diverse items for re-sale

Achat d’articles divers

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth E. is a fishmonger. She is married, but her husband's income as a fisherman is not sufficient for Elizabeth and her 5 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Elizabeth is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Aïssatou

texts.fr:
Mrs. Aïssatou N. is married with seven children in her care. She is requesting this loan to fund her business rearing table chickens and at the same time buy and sell cloth dyed using a resist-dye technique found in Senegal called "thioup.” She will thus be able to help improve the living conditions, health and survival of her family. This loan will be repaid in a single installment at the end of six months.  
Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer. 
Mme Aïssatou N. est mariée, avec 07 enfants à charge. Elle souhaite ce prêt pour financer son projet d’élevage de poulet de chaire et en même temps acheter et revendre des tissus teints « THIOUP ». Elle contribuera ainsi à améliorer les conditions de vie, de santé et de survie de sa famille. Ce prêt sera remboursé en une seule échéance au bout de six mois .

loans.use: To fund her project of rearing table chickens and also buy and sell cloth

loans.name: Matilda

texts.en:
Matilda B. sells groceries and owns the grocery store. She is married, but her husband's income as a fisherman is not sufficient for Matilda and her 4 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Matilda is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John A. is a fisherman. He is married, but his wife's income as a fishmonger is not sufficient to support John and his 5 children financially. Demand for his goods is high, and he is looking to expand his business to increase his profits.

John is asking for additional capital to expand his business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand his business

loans.name: Anna

texts.fr:
Mrs Anna K. is married and the mother of five children. She is requesting a loan to set up a business selling women’s clothing, watches and chains in order to help improve the living conditions and health of her family. She will repay the loan after six months in a single installment. 
Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

La dame Anna K. est mariée et mère de 05 enfants. Elle sollicite un prêt pour s’activer dans la vente d’habillement pour femme, de montre et de chaine afin de contribuer à l’amélioration des conditions de vie et de sa santé de sa famille. Elle va rembourser au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: To buy and sell women's clothing, chains and watches

loans.name: Murorunkwere

texts.en:
Murorunkwere S. Emerthe was born in 1963 and lives in Kimisagara. Murorunkwere was married in 1993, but her husband was killed one year later. She has three children and is in charge of two orphans. She began her business in 1996 taking a small amount of money from Nyarugenge money lenders (20,000RWF). She started selling crops. At the end of 1997, she had saved 450,000RWF. She started a new business going to Kampala to buy clothes and selling them in a small shop. She has been able to build a house with value of five million RWF.

She is requesting a loan of 500,890 RWF to increase her capital and expects to go to Dar-es-Salaam to purchase additional stock.

loans.use: Increase business capital

loans.name: Heremakono (Attente Du Bonheur) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Heremakono group are married women whose average age is 30 and who have, on average, 6 children each. They live in polygamous families with their husbands and children in the village of Sikouna 1, Fana Sous-Prefecture (Koulikoro region, Republic of Mali).

The principle business of this group of women is selling firewood, charcoal, and pottery. They have a place to store their wares in the country and near their concessions. The charcoal and firewood are bought from farmers who are licensed to participate in this business. They generally retail the charcoal in small quantities on a cash basis to a clientele made up essentially of women and sell it wholesale to foragers who come from the bigger cities such as Ségou and Bamako. Handicrafts, made by the women themselves, consisting of pots, “canaris” (earthenware jars for water), jars, incense burners, etc., are purchased in quantity in the village by wholesalers who come from the city.

United by professional and neighborhood ties, the members of the group are requesting their first group loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They plan to buy 25 sacks of charcoal (at 1000 FCFA, resold at 1500 FCFA) and thus make a monthly average profit of 12,500 FCFA which will go toward repayment of the loan and to bolster their businesses.

Please note that Malado K. is absent from the group photo because she was seeing a doctor at the Marka coungo infirmary.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Heremakono sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’age de 30 ans et 6 enfants .Elles vivent dans des familles polygames avec leurs maris et enfants dans le village de Sikouna 1 sous préfecture de Fana (Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali).

L’activité principale de ce groupe de femmes est la vente du bois de chauffe, du charbon de bois et la poterie. Elles disposent d’un lieu de stockage en brousse et devant leurs concessions. Le charbon de bois et le bois de chauffe sont achetés avec des paysans légalement reconnus dans l’exercice de ce métier. Elles vendent généralement le charbon de bois au comptant en détail à une clientèle essentiellement féminine et en gros aux forains venant des grandes villes comme Ségou et Bamako. Les produits de l’artisanat( fabriqués par elles même) que sont les pots les canaris les jarres les ensencoires etc. sont achetés en gros au village par des grossistes qui viennent de la ville.

Unies par des liens professionnels et de voisinage les membres du groupe sont à leur premier prêt solidaire avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles envisagent acheter 25 sacs de charbon (à 1000FCFA et vendu à1500FCFA) et ainsi réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 12 500FCFA. qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt et renforcer leurs activités.

Il est à noter que la nommée MALADO K. était allé pour consultation au centre de santé de Marka coungo, elle est absente de la photo de groupe.

loans.use:
Purchase of charcoal and various other items for re-sale

Achat de charbon de bois et d’articles divers

loans.name: Margarita Lisseth

texts.es:
Margarita is 26 years old and lives in the “Hialeah II Etapa” neighborhood. She is single and has no children.

Margarita works as a cashier at a bank in the city of Managua and at nights she goes to the university. She has been working as a cashier for a year.

Margarita’s house is half in concrete and the other half in zinc. That is why she requests a loan so that she can change all the zinc walls into concrete. She will do the changes little by little with the financing she will receive.

Margarita would like to have a better standard of living so that when she has a family, she can give her children the comforts they need.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

Margina tiene 26 años de edad, habita en el barrio Hialeah II etapa, es soltera y no tiene niños. Trabaja como cajera en un banco de managua, y por las noches asiste a la universidad. Tiene un año de experiencia trabajando como cajera. La casa de Margina actualmente es mitad de concreto y mitad de zinc. Ella quiere construir toda su casa de concreto. El préstamo solicitado es para cambiar la parte de las paredes hechas de zinc por concreto. Las mejoras espera realizarlas poco a poco y con financiamientos. Quiere tener una mejor condición de vida para cuando forme una familia, y por darles a sus hijos la comodidad que necesitan.

loans.use: To change all the zinc walls in her house to concrete

loans.name: Egya

texts.en:
Egya E. sells fish and owns a canoe. He is married, but his wife's income as a fishmonger is not sufficient for Egya and his 3 children. Demand for his goods is high, and he is looking to expand his business to increase his profits.

He is asking for additional capital to expand his business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand his business

loans.name: Silvia Elena

texts.es:
Mrs. Silvia is 57 years old and sells fruits and Nacatamales (local tamales served as breakfast on Sundays or lunch during the week) on Saturdays and Sundays. she is married and her 4 children are adults and live outside the home. 15 years ago, Mrs. Silvia started her business selling nacatamales, but over time was able to extend to the sale of fruits from her home.

Mrs. Silvia's husband is an electrician, but is currently unemployed, a situation that has brought Silvia to search for other sources of income. As a result she is requesting a loan in order to be able to purchase construction materials to make a small room in her house that she can rent and be able to count on other income the will permit her family to live comfortably and stably.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

Doña Silvia tiene 57 años de edad, se dedica a la venta de frutas y también vende Nacatamales los sábados y los domingos, es casada y sus 4 hijos ya son mayores de edad e independientes a ella. Hace 15 años Doña Silvia empezó el negocio de las ventas de nacatamales pero con el tiempo pudo extenderse también a la venta de frutas en su casa de habitación. El esposo de Doña Silvia es electricista pero en estos momentos se encuentra desempleado, situación que lleva a Doña Silvia a buscar otras fuentes de ingresos, es por eso que solicita el crédito, para la compra de materiales de construcción para hacer un pequeño cuarto en su vivienda, y así ponerlo de alquiler y poder contar con otros ingresos que le permitan a esta familia una condición de vida estable.

loans.use: Construction of a bedroom.

loans.name: Khady

texts.fr:
Khady D. is married and has been a member of the Boucotte village bank for six years. She is requesting this loan to strengthen her business so that she can better satisfy her customers. She will therefore continue to sell palm oil, dried fish and honey. She plans to repay the loan after six months in a single installment.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Khady D. est mariée et membre du banc villageois de Boucotte depuis 06ans. Elle souhaite ce prêt renforcer son marché afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. Elle va donc continuer à vendre de l’huile de palme, du poisson séchés et du miel. Elle compte faire le remboursement au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: To strengthen her business of selling dried fish, palm oil and honey

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba G. is a fishmonger. She is married, but her husband's income as a fisherman is not sufficient for Aba and her 3 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Aba is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr:
Fatou S. is married and has seven children in her care. She is requesting this loan to strengthen her business which consists of buying and selling vegetables and fabrics dyed with indigo using a resist-dye technique found in Senegal called "thioup.” She wants to use this loan to improve the health and living conditions of her family. This loan will be repaid in a single installment at the end of six months.
Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer. 
Fatou S. est mariée et a 07 enfants à charge. Elle souhaite ce prêt pour renforcer son activité qui consiste à acheter et à revendre des légumes et tissus teints à l’indigo « THIOUP ».Elle veut avec ce prêt améliorer les conditions de vie et de santé de sa famille. Ce prêt sera remboursé en une seule échéance au bout de six mois.

loans.use: To buy and sell vegetables and "thioup" fabrics

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.fr:
Born on August 12, 1977 in Zinvié, in Atlantique County, Ms. Charlotte O. is originally from Sakété, in Ouémé County. She is married and the mother of two. Her husband Germain ADEYE is a tailor-embroiderer by profession. She is improving in the sale of various goods, such as: sandalettes (flip-flop sandals), plates, drinking glasses, kitchen utensils, etc. She has been in sales and distribution for almost seven years and stocks up at the international marketplace of Cotonou. She is on her fifth loan. After the distribution of her different articles, she sees her customers to collect payment. Her plan is to get settled in a shop in order to limit trips to her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Née le 12 Août 1977 à Zinvié dans le département de l'Atlantique, dame O. Charlotte est originaire de Sakété dans le département de l'Ouémé. Elle est mariée et mère de deux enfants. Son mari ADEYE Germain est Couturier-Brodeur de profession. Elle évolue dans la vente de divers articles comme: les sandalettes, les assiettes, les vers à boire, les ustensiles de cuisine, etc. Elle est dans la distribution vente depuis près de sept ans et s'approvisionne au marché international de Cotonou. Elle est à son cinquième prêt. Après la distribution de ses différents articles, elle passe chez ses clients pour la collecte.Son projet est d'avoir une boutique pour s'installer afin de limiter les déplacements vers clients.

loans.use: To buy plastics, kitchen utensiles, plates, and various soaps

loans.name: Honronya (L’Indépendance) Group

texts.fr:
The members of Honronya group are on average 25 years old and have an average of 4 children each. They live in extended traditional families with their husbands and children in the village of Sikouna 1, Fana Sous-Prefecture, (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali).

The group sells various items: charcoal and especially condiments (smoked fish, dried fish, spices, salt, etc.)

They are linked to each other by ties of profession, neighborhood, and friendship.

Their solidarity being firmly established, the members of Honronya have decided to work with Soro Yiriwaso, which has just approved their first group loan. Their purchasing is done via wholesalers coming from Bamako, generally on market days as far as the condiments are concerned, and, as for charcoal, in surrounding villages. They sell their merchandise either out of their homes, or at the market, or as ambulant salespeople. Their sales are generally made retail on a cash basis, especially at the market, and on credit to neighbors in the village.

The members of the Honronya group, by buying with this loan 10 sacks of charcoal, 5 kg of smoked fish, 10 kg of dried fish, and big quantities of spices, expect to make an average monthly profit of 7500 FCFA which will be mostly reinvested in their businesses.

In future, these women of the Honronya group hope to become wholesalers.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Horonya, âgés de 25 ans avec 4 enfants en moyenne vivent dans des familles élargies traditionnelles avec leurs époux et enfants dans le village de Sikouna 1 sous préfecture de Fana (Région de Koulikoro République du Mali.)

Le groupe fait le commerce d’articles divers : de charbon de bois et surtout les condiments alimentaires (poisson fumé, séché, épices sel de cuisine etc.)

Elles sont essentiellement unies par des liens professionnels de voisinage et d’amitié.

La solidarité du groupe ne souffrant d’aucune faille les membres de Horonya ont décidé de travailler avec Soro Yiriwaso qui leurs a octroyé leur premier prêts de groupe ce mois ci .L’approvisionnement de ce groupe se fait auprès des grossistes venant de Bamako, généralement les jours de foire pour les condiments et dans les villages environnants pour le charbon de bois. Elles viennent vendre leurs articles suivant les cas à la maison soit au marché soit de façon ambulante .Les ventes de ce groupe se font généralement en détail au comptant au niveau du marché surtout, et à crédit aux voisins du village.

Les membres du groupe Horonya en achetant avec ce prêt 10 sacs de charbon de bois 5 kg de poisson fumé 10 kg de poisson séché et importante quantité d’épices comptent réaliser bénéfice un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 7500CFA qui serviront essentiellement à l’investissement dans l’activité.

Ces femmes de Horonya envisagent devenir des grossistes.

loans.use:
Purchase of various items for re-sale

Achat de divers articles

loans.name: Bladimir

texts.es:
Bladimir is 34 years old, married, and has 2 children, ages 16 and 3. His wife works at home, taking care of the children. Bladimir is employed as an external auditor, apart from which he owns a general store and some billiard tables which he rents out. He has 8 years experience in his business and started by selling candies and cleaning supplies. However, through loans he was able to obtain billiard tables to rent.

His plans for his business are to be able to increase the physical size of his business in order for their employees to be more comfortable and more independent of one another. While he is working (as an Auditor) his mother manages the store and the billiard tables. Some of the most demanded products for the store are basic grains and milk products, and with the loan that you grant him he will buy these products and also purchase more cleaning supplies.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

Bladimir tiene 34 años de edad, es casado, tiene 2 hijos de 16 y 3 años de edad, su esposa se encarga del cuido del hogar y de sus hijos. Bladimir se desempeña como Auditor Externo, pero aparte de eso tiene una pulpería y unas mesas de billares las cuáles alquila. Tiene 8 años de experiencia en este negocio y empezó vendiendo golosinas y productos de limpiezas, pero a través de los créditos a los que pudo acceder logró poner el alquiler de mesas de billar. Los planes para su negocio son poder agrandar el área física de su negocio para poder tener sus negocios más cómodos e independientes uno del otro. Mientras él está trabajando su madre es la encargada de administrar la pulpería y las mesas de billares. Uno de los productos más demandados para la pulpería son los granos básicos y los productos lácteos y con el crédito que le otorguen comprará dichos productos y también comprará productos de limpieza.

loans.use: Purchase of basic grains, milk products, and cleaning products.

loans.name: Yazmin Arely

texts.es:
Yazmín started her business because she liked working and having her own money to buy herself things as well as contributing to the household expenses to relieve some of the burden from her husband. She began her business selling tamales more than 2 years ago and initially only sold to close family. Gradually, she sold to more people, usually working on request so that her tamales didn’t sit unsold and so that she didn’t end up with a bad investment that could be very difficult to recover later.

She needs a $300 loan, which she will repay in six months, to purchase ingredients and put out requests for events and ultimately provide her customers with good service.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva volunteer.

Yazmín inició el negocio porque le gusta trabajar y tener su propio dinero para comprarme sus cosas, además de que también coopera con los gastos de la casa para que a su esposo no se le haga pesado. Comenzó su negocio de venta de tamales hace mas de dos años y en un inicio solo vendía a sus familiares cercanos, pero poco a poco fue vendiendo a mas personas, por lo general trabaja sobre pedido para que no se queden sin vender y que no resulte una mala inversión porque después es muy difícil recuperar.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $300 que pagara en 6 meses el cual le servirá para comprar materia prima y poder sacar varios pedidos para eventos y hay que darles un buen servicio a sus clientes.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients.

loans.name: Mukawera

texts.en:
Mukawera J. was born in 1961. She lives in Gatsata. She has been a widow since 1994 when her husband died during the genocide. They had four children when her husband died. After the genocide, she took another three orphans under her charge. Currently, one child is in secondary school while the others are in primary school. In 1996, with 20,000 RWF as capital, she began selling dresses second-hand in the local market. At the end of the year, she had 80,000 RWF as capital.

She came to VFC requesting a loan in order to increase her capital and diversify the goods she sells. She wants a loan to begin a new kind of business selling tires.

loans.use: Increase her business capital

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria is 57 years old, and married with one child, who has completed school and is working. She trades in curtain and suiting materials, upholsteries, flowers, perfumes, jewelry, and other items in the town of Koforidua. Due to low working capital, she sometimes buys her supplies on credit and repays the cost at high interest after sales. She wants to use the loan of $975 to purchase bulk quantities of curtain and suiting fabric, upholstery material, flowers, perfumes, jewelry etc. to enable her reduce the cost of sales and increase her income. She hopes to use part of her profit to acquire decent shelter for her family in future. She is a member of the community group called Evergreen Trust Group. The group guarantees a loan through repayment pledge.

loans.use: To purchase bulk curtain and suiting fabric, upholstery material, flowers, perfumes and other goods

loans.name: Kelenya (L’Unité) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Kelenya group, 20 years old and with 4 children on average, live in extended traditional families with their husbands, co-spouses, and children in the village of Sikouna 1, Sub-Prefecture Fana (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali).

The members of the group sell various items: condiments (smoked fish, dried fish, fresh tomatoes, etc.), fresh cow’s milk, cosmetics, fruit and vegetables, etc.

They are bound together essentially by profession, neighborhood, friendship, or are related to each other.

Their firm solidarity has motivated the members of Kelenya to become part of the lending program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso which has just approved their first group loan. The members of the group do their purchasing exclusively from wholesalers who come from populous areas such as Bamako, Ségou, and Fana once a week to the market fair at Marka coungo. They sell their wares either at home (in the village) or in the market in stalls, or as ambulant salespeople. Their sales are generally retail on a cash basis and also on credit.

The members of Kelenya group intend to buy 5 kg of fish, 5 kg of spices, 2 baskets of fresh tomatoes, 3 baskets of fruit and vegetables. They hope to use this loan to make a monthly average profit of 7500 FCFA, which will essentially be reinvested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Kelenya, âgés de 20 ans avec 4 enfants en moyenne vivent dans des familles élargies traditionnelles avec leurs époux, coépouses, et enfants dans le village de Sikouna 1sous préfecture de Fana ( Région de Koulikoro République du Mali.)

Le groupe fait le commerce d’articles divers : les condiments alimentaires (poisson fumé, séché, épices tomate frais etc.) le lait frais de vache, les cosmétiques, les fruits et légumes etc.

Elles sont essentiellement unies par des liens professionnels de voisinage d’amitié et de parenté.

La solidité de l’unité de ce groupe qui ne souffre d’aucune faille a motivé les membres de Kelenya à intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso qui vient de leurs octroyer leur premier prêt de groupe. Ce groupe s’approvisionne exclusivement auprès des grossistes venant des grandes agglomérations comme Bamako Ségou et Fana une fois par semaine à la foire de Marka coungo. Elles vendent leurs articles suivant les cas à la maison (au village) soit au marché sous des hangars soit de façon ambulante .Les ventes de ce groupe se font généralement au comptant en détail et aussi à crédit.

Les membres groupe Kelenya comptent acheter 5kg de poissons 5kg d’épices 2 paniers de tomates frais 3 paniers de fruits et légumes Elles espèrent réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice moyen et mensuel de 7500FCFA qui servira essentiellement à l’investissement dans l’activité.

loans.use:
Purchase of various items for re-sale

Achat d’articles divers

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul is 30 years old and has two children. He owns a boutique and sells women's clothing, shoes, and accessories. He has been in business for the past 4 years. Paul has observed that selling women's clothing is a better business than selling men's clothes, because men hardly ever buy new clothes. Paul would like a loan of $975 to help him meet his customers' demand for quality clothes, bags and shoes. He believes that with the loan he will be able to improve the quality and stock of inventory in his shop. He belongs to the community group called Adonai Trust Group. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy increased stock of ladies' clothing, slippers, and purses

loans.name: Victoire

texts.fr:
Originally from Sakété in the Ouémé department, Mrs. Victoire A. was born on 1st September 1967. She is married and has 4 children, all adults. She does not live with her husband. Having settled and survived by herself for a decade, she is very dynamic and organized in her work. She owns her own shop situated in Agongbomey, where she sells various convenience goods. She travels to neighbouring Nigeria herself to make her purchases.She is asking for her very first loan, and would like to have a larger shop in order to enlarge her business.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

Originaire de Sakété dans le département de l'Ouémé, dame A. Victoire est née le 01/09/1967. Elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants tous majeurs. Elle ne vit pas avec son mari. Installée à son propre compte depuis une dizaine d'année elle est très dynamique et organisée dans son travail. Elle possède sa propre boutique située à Agongbomey où elle vend divers produits de consommation courante. Elle se rend elle même au Nigéria voisin pour faire ses achats. Elle est à son tout premier crédit et voudrait disposer d'une plus grande boutique pour des besoins de croissance.

loans.use: To buy one box of food paste, and 2 boxes of canned food

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana is 42 years old. She is a wife and mother of two children. Dianna is a resourceful, hardworking mother and a successful business woman. One of her children is currently in school. She trades in women's shoes and slippers, children's shoes, and sachet water in the Koforidua market. Diana has inadequate working capital to grow her business but she believes that with the loan, she will be able to provide her customers with higher-quality shoes and slippers, and buy more goods to sell at the market. She hopes to raise good income to support her family. She belongs to the community group called ‘Nyame mmere’ (meaning, God’s time) Trust Group. In this group, members agree to guarantee  each other as social collateral to repay the loans.

loans.use: To buy more ladies' slippers and shoes, children's shoes, and other items for resale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Konotieyele (La Lumière De L’Oiseau Male) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Konotieyele group are married women, aged 38 and with 7 children on average. They live in polygamous families with their husbands and children in the village of Konobougou, Sub-Prefecture of Baroueli (Ségou Region, Republic of Mali).

The principal business activity of these women of the Konotieyele group (so named in memory of the founder of the village: male bird Diarra) is the sale of firewood and charcoal which they buy from farmers (supplying the village of Konobougou) who have a permit to cut wood. They have storerooms in their husbands’ compounds and generally sell charcoal retail to a local clientele (women, men) and wholesale to buyers who come out to the country from the big towns like Ségou and Bamako.

United by ties of profession and neighborhood and very active in economic activities, the members of the group are requesting their third group loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, having repaid prior loans correctly. With this loan they intend to buy 80 sacks of charcoal and 5 loads of firewood and hope to make an average monthly profit of 35000 FCFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan, to pay for family necessities, and above all bolster their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Konotieyele sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’age de 38 ans et 7 enfants .Elles vivent dans des familles polygames avec leurs maris et enfants dans le village de konobougou sous préfecture de Baroueli (Région de Ségou République du Mali)

L’activité principale de ce groupe de femmes Konotieyele(en mémoire au fondateur du village konotiè :oiseau male Diarra) est la vente du bois de chauffe et du charbon de bois, qu’elles achètent avec les paysans (ravitaillant le village de Konobougou) et qui détiennent des permis de coupe de bois. Elles disposent d’un lieu de stockage dans la concession conjugale et vendent généralement le charbon de bois en détail à une clientèle locale (femmes hommes) et en gros aux forains venant des grandes villes comme Ségou et Bamako.

Unies par des liens professionnels, de voisinage et très entreprenants dans les activités économiques, les membres du groupe sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso avec un remboursement correct. Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt 80 sacs charbon de bois et 5 chargements de bois de chauffe et espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35000FCFA. qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux besoins de la famille et surtout renforcer leurs activités.

loans.use:
Purchase of charcoal and diverse items for re-sale

Achat de charbon ce bois et d’articles divers

loans.name: San Juana

texts.es:
San Juana started her business to help her husband with the household expenses and to have an activity that would keep her busy, but also allow her to care for her children and maintain her house. She began her grocery store with her mother’s help since she was unable to work and she didn’t have anyone to care for her children for about three years. She hopes to succeed and put a lot of effort into her business to provide her customers with good service and earn good profits.

She needs a $200 loan, which she will repay in six months, to restock her merchandise and to buy new products for the store that customers have been requesting. With your help, San Juana will succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva volunteer.

San Juana inició el negocio por la necesidad de ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa y de la familia y tener alguna actividad para mantenerse ocupada y al mismo tiempo cuidar a sus hijos y realizar las actividades de la casa. Comenzó su tienda de abarrotes con la ayuda de su mama debido a que ella ya no pudo trabajar porque tuvo hijos y no tenia quien se los cuidara hace aproximadamente 3 años. Ella desea salir adelante y echarle muchas ganas al negocio para dar un buen servicio al cliente y así mismo para obtener buenas ganancias.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $200 que pagara en 6 meses para resurtir mercancía y para comprar nuevos productos en la tienda que le han estado solicitando. con tu ayuda San Juana saldra adelante.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and restock grocery store.

loans.name: Laidou (Promesse) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Laidou group are married. Their average age is 22; they have, on average, 3 children and live in traditional families with their spouses, co-spouses, and children in the village of Konobougou, Prefecture of Baroueli (Ségou Region, Republic of Mali).

They sell various small items (cosmetics, condiments, clothing, sugar, tea, cigarettes, etc.)

The women of Laidou group do their purchasing essentially on market fair days in Konobougou from wholesalers who are specialized in the items mentioned above. They generally sell retail on a cash basis at established market stalls or as ambulant salespeople in the village. Their clientele is mostly female with a few males.

The group is presently on its third loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, and all the preceding loans were reimbursed in a timely manner.

They want to use this loan to buy: 5 cartons of cigarettes, 1 small case of tubes of skin crème, 5 kg of fish, 10 pants, shirts or dresses for children, and a large quantity of condiments.

With this loan they hope to make a weekly average profit of 2500 FCFA, i.e., monthly 10,000 FCFA per member.

Each of them hopes to open a little shop and specialize in one item.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Laidou sont mariés avec une moyenne d’age de 22 ans 3 enfants et vivant dans des familles traditionnelles avec leurs époux, coépouses et enfants dans le village de Konobougou préfecture de Baroueli( Région de Ségou République du Mali)

Elles exercent le petit commerce d’articles divers (cosmétique, condiments alimentaires, habillements, sucre, thé, cigarettes etc.)

Les femmes du groupe Laidou s’approvisionnent essentiellement les jours de foire du village de Konobougou auprès des grossistes qui se sont spécialisés dans le domaine des articles ci-dessus cités. Elles revendent généralement en détail au comptant de façon fixe au marché ou ambulante dans des tasses de porte en porte au niveau du village. La clientèle à dominance féminine compte quelques hommes.

Le groupe est à son troisième prêt avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.

Elles veulent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter : 5 cartouches de cigarettes 1 petit carton de tube et lotion pour la peau 5kg de poissons 10 pantalons chemises ou robes pour enfants et une grande quantité de condiments.

Elles espèrent réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice hebdomadaire moyen de 2500FCFA soit un mensuel de 10 000FCFA par membre.

Elles souhaitent ouvrir chacune une boutique et se spécialiser au d’un article.

loans.use:
Purchase of various items for re-sale

Achat de divers articles

loans.name: Djahéli

texts.fr:
At 30 years of age, Mrs. Djahéli H. is married and has 3 children, 2 of whom are in school. A very dynamic woman, she puts all her energy into her business. She has been selling a paste, known as "kom" in Agbodjèdo, for more than two years, and other food goods. This paste, made from a maize base, is accompanied by a spicy fish sauce. This paste is highly prized by the residents of Cotonou, especially those who are of "Guin" ethnicity. She is asking for this loan to stop having to buy maize at retail, so as to increase her profits.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

Agée de 30 ans, dame H. Djahéli est mariée et mère de trois enfants dont 2 scolarisés. Femme très dynamique, elle met toute son énergie dans son activité. Elle vend la pâte localement appelée "kom" à Agbodjèdo il y a plus de deux ans et des produits vivriers. Cette pâte faite à base de maïs est accompagnée d'une sauce au poisson assez pimentée. Cette pâte est très admirée par les habitants de Cotonou surtout ceux qui sont de l'ethnie "Guin". Elle sollicite ce prêt pour rompre avec l'achat de maïs au détail afin de majorer ses bénéfices.

loans.use: To buy 5 bowls worth of maize and 5 bowls worth of manioc flour

loans.name: Laidou 2 (Promesse) Group

texts.fr:
The members of this Laidou group are all married. On average, they are 36 years old and have 5 children. They live in traditional families with their husbands, co-spouses, and children in Fana coura, a neighborhood in the sub-prefecture of the same name (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali).

The Laidou group sells decorative rugs, carpeting, women’s clothing, cosmetics, and a number of other articles for women.

As the members of this group are related to each other or bound by ties of friendship, they have confidence in each other and continue to borrow as a group through Soro Yiriwaso.

They are on their fourth group loan and have not missed a payment. Whereas the rugs and carpets are purchased from the Islamic Republic of Mauritania, the lengths of African print cloth and such come from Bamako, capital of the Republic of Mali. The sale of these articles is essentially on credit, payable weekly or monthly. The clientele is mostly made up of women and workers.

With this loan they intend to buy 6 carpets at 15,000 FCFA each to resell for 22,500 FCFA and Dutch “wax” print cloth at 4000 FCFA sold for 5500 FCFA.

They expect to make a monthly profit of 30,000 FCFA with which they will make payments on the loan and bolster their businesses.

The members of the group hope to organize themselves and protect their interests by becoming an legal, registered company.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Laidou sont toutes mariées avec une moyenne d’age de 36 ans et 5 enfants .Elles vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, coépouses et enfants à Fana coura un des quartiers de la sous préfecture du même nom (Région de Koulikoro République du Mali.)

Le groupe Laidou fait le commerce de tapis de décoration, de moquette d’habillements féminin, des produits de beauté, et bien d’autres articles pour femmes.

Ce groupe a des relations de parenté et d’amitié qui fait que les membres se font confiance et continuent à emprunter ensemble au niveau de Soro Yiriwaso.

Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt de solidarité et n’ont aucun arriéré de paiement .Tandis que les tapis, moquettes sont achetés à partir de la République Islamique de Mauritanie les pagnes et autres viennent de Bamako capitale de la République du Mali .La vente de ces articles se fait essentiellement à crédit payable hebdomadairement ou mensuellement. La clientèle est à majorité constituée de femmes et de travailleurs.

Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter 5 tapis moquettes à 15000FCFA l’unité et revendre à 22500FCFA et les pagnes wax hollandais à 4000FCFA et revendus 5500FCFA

Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30000FCFA avec lequel les intérêts du prêt seront payés et l’activité renforcée.

Les membres du groupe envisagent s’organiser pour défendre leurs intérêts en créant un GIE.

loans.use:
Purchase of cloth, cosmetics, and various items for re-sale

Achat de pagnes de cosmétiques et d’articles divers

loans.name: Darlin Del Socorro

texts.es:
In the town of Nagarote, which is part of the city of León, Darlin M. works very hard in her home business of raising pigs. She has been working at this for the past three years and she does it in order to maintain her humble one-room house.

Darlin is seeking support from Ceprodel, with the goal of obtaining credit with which to purchase pigs. It is for this reason that she has turned to the institution hoping that her loan will be approved. That way she will be able to keep up with the maintenance of her home. She has had three loans and paid them all back on time, according to the policies of the institution.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

En el municipio de Nagarote de la ciudad de León, la señora Darling M. se dedica muy esforzadamente a su negocio de crianza de cerdos en su propia casa de habitación. Se dedica a esta labor desde hace 3 años y hoy lo hace para mantener su humilde hogar de habitación que tanto necesita de su apoyo.

Hoy en día, la señora Darling busca el apoyo en Ceprodel con el propósito único de obtener un crédito para la compra de los cerdos. Es por esta razón que acude a la institución esperando que su crédito le sea otorgado y de esta manera salir adelante con el mantenimiento de su hogar de habitación en su sector. Actualmente ella posee un total de tres créditos habiéndolos cancelado todos en tiempo y forma de acuerdo a lo establecido en la institución.

loans.use: To buy pigs

loans.name: Karla Susana

texts.es:
Karla decided to sell shoes through a catalog in order to earn some extra income in addition to her partner’s salary and thus improve their children’s quality of life. She began selling shoes from her home to family members, and after a few recommendations people began to know her. This is how she started her sales business and she’s now been in business for four years.

She needs a $200 loan, which she will repay in six months, to buy shoes for school season since the start of classes is approaching and she wants to have enough merchandise. With your help Karla will succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva volunteer.

Karla decidió ponerse a vender zapatos por catalogo para obtener algún ingreso extra ademas del sueldo de su pareja y así poder darles mejor calidad de vida a sus hijos. Empezó vendiendo los productos en su casa a sus familiares y después por recomendaciones la gente empezo a conocerla y fue así como ella inicio sus ventas y ya tiene 4 años con esta actividad.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $200 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar zapatos de temporada ya que se acerca el regreso a clases y quiere tener suficiente mercancia. Con tu ayuda Karla saldra adelante.

loans.use: To purchase shoes.

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.fr:
Born around 1968 in Abomey Calavi in the Atlantique department in the south of BENIN, Mrs. Jeanne E. is married and has 6 children, of which the eldest, Anne-marie, is 25 years old, and the youngest, Terrence, is 12. She is a seamstress by profession, but in parallel with this she sells yams and fried sweet potatoes. The demands of her customers are increasing and her financial means are unable to meet them; she is asking for this loan of 100,000 francs to supply herself in order to increase her production and respond appropriately to the demands of her clientele.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

Née vers les années 1968 à Abomey Calavi dans le département de l'Atlantique au sud du BENIN, dame E. Jeanne est mariée et mère de 06 enfants dont l'aînée Anne-marie a 25 ans et le benjamin Terrance a 12 ans. Elle est couturière de profession, mais elle mène parallèlement à cette profession la vente d'igname et patate douce frites. La demande de sa clientèle étant croissante et les moyens financiers n'étant pas au rendez vous; elle sollicite ce prêt de 100 000 francs pour s'approvisionner afin d' augmenter sa production et de répondre convenablement aux demandes de sa clientèle.

loans.use: To buy 1 bag of wheat flour, 2 bags of yams, and 1 bag of sweet potatoes.

loans.name: Mougnou (Patience) Group

texts.fr:
The members of Mougnou group, with an average age of 30 and 6 children on average, live in traditional extended families in the village of Sikouna 1, Sub-prefecture of Fana (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali).

The group sells various items: cigarettes, tea, clothing, condiments (smoked fish, dried fish, spices, etc.)

They are essentially bound by ties of neighborhood, similar age, and friendship.

The solidarity of the group being firm, the members of Mougnou have decided to work together with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso which has approved their first group loan this month.

They do their purchasing from wholesalers who come from Bamako and Ségou to market days in Marka coungo. They sell their goods either from home or at the market or as ambulant salespeople. Their sales are generally retail and on a cash basis.

The members of the group intend to buy 25 kg of fish, 5 kg of spices, packets of tea, a carton of cigarettes and some clothing items. With this loan, they hope to make a profit of 7500 FCFA which will be used essentially for reinvesting in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Mougnou avec une moyenne d’age de âgé de 30 ans et 6 enfants vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Sikouna 1 sous préfecture de Fana (Région de Koulikoro République du Mali.)

Le groupe fait le commerce d’articles divers : cigarettes, thé, habillements, et les condiments alimentaires (poisson fumé, séché, épices etc.)

Elles sont essentiellement unies par des liens de voisinage, de groupe d’age et d’amitié.

La solidarité du groupe ne souffrant d’aucune faille les membres de Mougnou ont décidé ensemble de collaborer avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso qui leurs a octroyé leur premier prêt de groupe ce mois ci.

L’approvisionnement de ce groupe se fait exclusivement auprès des grossistes venant de Bamako et Ségou les jours de foire de Marka coungo. Elles revendent leurs articles suivant les cas à la maison soit au marché soit de façon ambulante .Les ventes de ce groupe se font généralement en détail au comptant.

Les membres du groupe comptent acheter 25kg de poissons 5kg d’épices des paquets de thé une cartouche de cigarettes et quelques habits. Elles espèrent réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice de 7500FCFAqui servira essentiellement à l’investissement dans l’activité.

Ces femmes de Mougnou envisagent devenir des grossistes.

loans.use:
purchase of various items for re-sale

Achat d’articles divers

loans.name: Yrma Edit

texts.es:
Yrma is a member of the "Solidarity" Communal Bank. She lives at Jr. Maya de Brito Nº 651 in the Calleria District of the Ucayali area. She is a 47-year-old mother with 4 children, 3 of whom are older in age and 1 younger in age. She is married, and her husband works as a carrier. With her first loan from Kiva field partner Manuela Ramos, Yrma invested in a small store.

Yrma rises at 6:00am in order to buy perishable products to be sold that day. She waits on customers at the same time she does chores around the house. Yrma's store is open until 9:00pm each night.

With a loan of S/. 1,800 to be re-paid in 5 months, Yrma will buy 3 sacks of rice, 3 sacks of sugar, 2 oil buckets, 3 packages of hygienic paper, 1 box of milk, 21 packages of detergent, 2 boxes of eggs, 1 soda water box, and treats; in this way, she will be able to increase sales in her store.

Yrma is very happy. She started her business little by little. Her greatest wish is that her 15-year-old daughter will be able to become a working professional. Thanks to Manuela Ramos, her business has grown. She has more clients and economic stability than she had dreamed of for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Yrma pertenece al Banco Comunal “Solidaridad”, su domicilio esta ubicado en el Jr. Maya de Brito Nº 651 del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 47 años y es madre de 4 hijos 3 mayores y 1 menor de edad, es casada, su esposo trabaja como Transportista. Con el primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en una pequeña bodega.

En la actualidad Yrma tiene que se levantarse a las 6.00 am. para salir a comprar sus productos comestibles para su venta del día y pueda atender a sus clientes al mismo tiempo que se dedica a los quehaceres de su casa. Yrma cierra su negocio a las 9:00pm.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,800 soles, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará 3 sacos de arroz, 3 sacos de azúcar, 2 baldes de aceite, 3 paquetes de papel higiénico, 1 caja de leche, 21 paquete de detergente, 2 jabas de huevo, 1 caja de gaseosa y golosinas, así podrá aumentar sus ventas en su bodega.

Yrma está muy contenta, empezó poco a poco y su mas grande deseo es que su hija de 15 años pueda ser una gran profesional, gracias a Manuela Ramos su negocio ha crecido, tiene mas clientes y estabilidad económica que tanto anhelaba para su familia.

loans.use:
Wholesale purchase of groceries
Compra al por mayor de diversos productos (abarrotes)

loans.name: Julieta

texts.es:
Juliet has three children who are the most important things in her life. Therefore, when she realized that the family wasn't getting by on her husband's salary, she decided to help with household expenses by doing something that came easily to her like making meals such as tamales and also selling cosmetics through a catalog. She began business out of economic necessity since her husband was going through a period where he really was not working. She started approximately 5 years ago, selling house-to-house and now has a good number of customers.

She needs a $200 loan, which she will repay in six months, to buy merchandise and fill an order of cosmetics that is pending.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva volunteer.

Julieta tiene tres hijos y son lo mas importante para ella es por eso que cuando vio que ya no completaban con el sueldo de su esposo decidió ayudar a los gastos de la casa con actividades fácil de realizar para ella como fue la elaboracion de comida: tamales y también a la venta de cosmeticos por catalogo Inició el negocio por necesidades económicas ya que su esposo estaba pasando por una situación donde realmente no había trabajo. Comenzó hace aproximadamente 5 años saliendo a vender casa por casa y ahora ya cuenta con una buena cantidad de clientes.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $200 que pagara en 6 meses para comprar mercancia y surtir un pedido de cosmeticos que tiene pendiente.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Yessica

texts.es:
Yessica is a member of the Lilies II Communal Bank, located in Jr. Comandante Barrera 276 in the Calleria District in the Ucayali area of Peru. She is 26 years old and has one son; her husband is a mechanic. With the first loan received from Manuela Ramos in the amount of S/. 300, she started a business selling local fruits. She wants to continue in this line of work, selling fruits and beverages of the region (aguaje, hungurahui, maní and other refreshments).

With the requested loan of S/ 1,200, which is to be repaid in 5 months, she will buy sacks of aguaje fruit, hungurahui fruit, trays and glasses. Additionally, she will make modifications in her sales module and will pay for a Municipal license.

Yessica is very grateful to the Manuela Ramos Bank for their support. She realizes that implementing her own business will allow her to take care of her own as well as her family's needs.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva vounteer.

La señora Yessica pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Azucenas II, ubicado en el Jr. Comandante Barrera 276, Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 26 años y tiene un hijo y su esposo es Mecánico, Sonia con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 implemento su negocio en venta de frutas regionales. En la actualidad sigue con el negocio de venta de frutas y bebidas regionales (aguaje hungurahui, maní y refrescos).

Con este préstamo recibido de S/ 1,200 el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará varios sacos de aguajes, hungurahui, bandejas, vasos. Además hará arreglos en su módulo de venta y pagará el permiso Municipal.

Yessica está muy agradecida con el Banco Manuela Ramos por el apoyo que le brinda y además se siente realizada dado que puede atender algunas necesidades propias de ella así como de su familia, por ello el deseo de seguir implementado su negocio.

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of fruits (aguaje, hungurahui) and utensils. Payment of municipal license.

loans.name: Louise

texts.fr:
Mrs. Louise K. is 28 years old and was born in Sahouè in the COUFFO department in the southwest BENIN. Married to a carpenter, she is the mother of 2 children : Claude, who is 7 years old and in class CP (equivalent to 1st grade), and Narcisse, who is 10 months old. She has run a business selling ready-to-eat meals for more than 3 years. She does not have any formal job training, but has devoted herself to this business, which provides her with more value. Currently, she is facing several financial difficulties in supplying herself with products, and she also envisions enlarging her array of goods. Faced with this situation, she is asking for her second loan, a sum of 100,000 francs, in order to better satisfy the demands of her clientele.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

Agée de 28 ans dame K. Louise est née à Sahouè dans le département du COUFFO au sud-ouest du BENIN. Mariée à un menuisier, elle est mère de 02 enfants: Claude 07ans en classe de CP et Narcisse âgé de 10 mois. Elle exerce l'activité de vente de repas prêt à manger depuis plus de 03 ans. Elle n'a rien appris comme métier et s'est consacrée à cette activité qui lui procure de plus value. Actuellement, elle éprouve quelques difficultés financières pour l'approvisionnement de ses produits mais aussi, envisage-t-elle d'agrandir son étalage. Face à cette situation, elle sollicite pour son deuxième crédit une somme de 100 000 francs afin de satisfaire au mieux aux demandes de sa clientèle.

loans.use: To buy 2 bags of rice, 1 can of peanut oil, and 2 boxes of food paste

loans.name: Sabougnouma (Porte Bonheur) Group

texts.fr:
The members of Sabougnouma group are married, 32 years old on average, and have an average of 8 children. They live in traditional families with their husbands, co-spouses, and children in the village of Sikouna 2, Sub-prefecture of Fana (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali).

The women of the Sabougnouma group are specialized in the sale of condiments: onions, pepper, tomato concentrate, dried and smoked fish, Magi cubes, greens, vermicelli, salt, etc.

The Sabougnouma group, made up of relatives, friends, and co-habitants, is on its first loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.

They want to use this loan to buy 1 kg of tomato concentrate, 1 packet of Magi cubes, 1 basket of onions, 5 kg of fish and some piles of greens on market days in Fana, Marka coungo, or Santiguila from the wholesalers who attend these weekly markets. The afore-mentioned locations are the traditional place for this group of village women to do their purchasing.

Their sales are made retail and on a cash basis in the village out of their homes or as ambulant salespeople going through the lanes from door to door. Their clientele is mainly composed of women with a few men.

With this loan, they expect to make a monthly average profit of 5000 FCFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan and invest in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Sabougnouma sont mariés avec une moyenne d’age de 32 ans 8 enfants et vivant dans des familles traditionnelles avec leurs époux, coépouses et enfants dans le village de Sikouna 2 sous préfecture de Fana( Région de Koulikoro République du Mali)

Les femmes du groupe Sabougnouma se sont spécialisées dans le commerce de condiments : oignon, poivre, concentré de tomate, poissons : séché, fumé, les aromes magi, les feuilles vertes, les vermicelles, le sel de cuisine etc.).

Le groupe Sabougnouma, constitué de parentes d’amies et de convives est à son premier prêt avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso.

Elles veulent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter 1 kg de concentré de tomate 1 paquet de cube magi 1 panier d’oignon 5kg de poissons et quelques tas de feuilles vertes les jours de foire de Fana, Marka coungo ou Santiguila auprès des grossistes fréquentant ces marchés hebdomadaires .Les localités ci-dessus citées constituent les lieux d’approvisionnement traditionnel de ce groupe de femmes entièrement villageois.

Elles effectuent généralement leurs ventes en détail au comptant au village à domicile de façon fixe ou ambulante dans des vanes de porte en porte .La clientèle est surtout composée de femmes et de quelques hommes.

Elles comptent réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 5000FCFA qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt et investir dans l’activité.
