loans.use: Sellign fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Shahlo

texts.en:
N. Shahlo is 26 years old. She is married and is the loving mother of two children. Shahlo has been in business since 2000. She embroiders national skull-caps for men and women. Shahlo produces national skull-caps of various types. As a result, she has many clients and usually there are many orders. Her mother-in-law helps her with the business. Shahlo sells the skull-caps in the local market. The business is stable and enables Shahlo to contribute significant income to the family budget.

Shahlo requests 800 USD for the term of 12 months. The loan is required to purchase fabric for embroidering the national skull-caps. Shahlo thanks everyone for supporting her and promises to repay the loan in time.

loans.use: Purchase fabric for embroidering the national skull-caps.

loans.name: Islomjon

texts.en:
S. Islomjon is 39 years old. He is married with three children. Islomjon sells confectioneries such as candies, cookies, pastries, and fruit jelly. He has been in this business for about 6 years. Islomjon buys the goods from the neighboring country of Uzbekistan. He has been working with IMON for more than two years and has a positive credit history. The generated income allows Islomjon to support his large family. He also has dreams to educate all of his children with higher education.

Islomjon requests 800 USD for the term of 6 months. He is going to use the loan to purchase more confectioneries and expand his range of goods. He plans to use his income to purchase the private store as well as to educate his children. Islomjon thanks you for all of your support and promises to repay the loan in time.

loans.use: Expand the range of goods and purchase the private store

loans.name: Ahadjon

texts.en:
V. Ahadjon is 31 years old. He is married with three children. Ahadjon drives a taxi car. He has been engaged in this work for more than five years. The current business is the main source of income for his large family. In addition to his children and wife, he is also supporting his parents and brothers. Ahadjon has told us that this type of work requires a lot of effort. In order to obtain a decent wage he has to work at night, particularly in the early morning hours. Ahadjon has to get up early and go to bed late to try to not to lose any clients. Ahadjon has no higher education but he wants this for his children and younger brothers.

Ahadjon wants to fix his car in order to provide higher quality services and earn more to support his younger brothers with a higher education. Ahadjon requests 600 USD for the term of 6 months. He is planning to purchase spare parts for his car. The well-being of this family is in your hands. Help them by contributing to the growth of Ahadjon’s business, and they will sincerely thank you.

loans.use: Purchasing the spare parts for the car.

loans.name: Rohat

texts.en:
Z. Rohat is 39 years old. She is married with 3 children. Rohat embroiders and sells national skull-caps for men in the local market. She has been in this business for 28 years. She learned this skill from her grandmother and now she is teaching her daughters. Rohat 's husband came from Russia and is currently unemployed. Her husband has heart disease and can’t be engaged in hard labor. Rohat is supporting the family by herself with the help of her daughter, who is pictured on the photo.

Rohat wants to expand the business and generate income to improve the living conditions for her family. With this purpose she needs 950 USD for the term of 12 months. She plans to purchase fabric to embroider national skull-caps. Rohat is counting on your help. Be an important part of the growth of Rohat’s business.

loans.use: Purchase the fabrics for embroidering the national skull-caps.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret A. is a 50 year old widow. She lives in Dunga with her seven children. Four are in school. Margaret buys traditional mats in bulk and supplies them to her customers at the market. She has applied for US $600 to further expand her business.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: For business expansion

loans.name: Thi Vinh's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. T. Thi Vinh (ID Number 03110033), born in 1973, would like to borrow 3,180,000VND to expand her confectionery shop. Her family owns this small shop to meet the demand of all the local people so she always needs more capital to purchase more goods. Her husband works in a steel and iron factory with other men in the village. Her family's average monthly income is 4,000,000VND (about 250USD). However, this income is still not enough as she has to raise 3 school-going children. She has asked her neighbours to join her and form a group to apply for loans. She was voted to be the group leader. Her group also consists of:

Mrs. H. Thi Nha (ID Number 03110029), born in 1983, would like to borrow 3,180,000VND to purchase more wood to craft.

Mrs. Dam Thi Hang (ID Number 03110031), born in 1987, would like to borrow 3,180,000VND to invest in breeding pigs.

Mrs. T. Thi Luan (ID Number 03110032), born in 1985, would like to borrow 3,180,000VND to purchase more wood to craft.

Mrs. K. Thi Bao (ID Number 03110030), born in 1984, would like to borrow 3,180,000VND to purchase more wood to craft.

The total amount requested is 950USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Trần Thị Vĩnh (Ms 03110033), sinh năm 1973, mức vay: 3.180.000 vnđ để đầu tư mở rộng cửa hàng bán bánh kẹo.Gia đình chị có cửa hàng nhỏ phục vụ những người dân xung quanh nên luôn cần vốn để có thể mua được nhiều mặt hàng hơn. Chồng chị hàng ngày đi làm sắt cùng những người trong thôn, thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 4.000.000 vnđ/ tháng. Song, gia đình chị còn nhiều vất vả vì vẫn còn phải nuôi 3 con ăn học.Chị đã mạnh dạn rủ những người hàng xóm thành lập tổ vay vốn và chị được bầu làm nhóm trưởng. Trong nhóm chi có: Hoàng Thị Nhạ (Ms 03110029), sinh năm 1983, mức vay: 3.180.000 vnđ để mua gỗ về đục gọt đồ thủ công mỹ nghệ. Đàm Thị Hằng (Ms 03110031), sinh năm 1987, mức vay: 3.180.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn. Trần Thị Luận (Ms 03110032), sinh năm 1985, mức vay:3.180.000 vnđ để đầu tư gỗ đục gọt hàng thủ công. Kiều Thị Bạo(Ms03110030), snh năm 1984, mức vay: 3.180.000 vnđ để đầu tư đồ gỗ mỹ nghệ.

loans.use: invest in confectionery shop

loans.name: Thi Hien's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi Hien (ID Number 03110006), born in 1979, would like to borrow 3,180,000VND to purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell. Her husband, like many other men in the village, is a factory worker in the steel and iron factory in Da Hoi, Dong Anh, Ha Noi city, thus earning stable income. Besides, Mrs. Hien sells fruits and vegetables in the market, so her family's average monthly income is about 3,500,000VND (about 225USD). She has 2 small children. With her current income, she can easily repay the loan on an installment basis. Her group also consists of:

Mrs. Nguyen Thi Su (ID Number 03110036), born in 1973, would like to borrow 3,180,000VND to invest in breeding pigs.

Mrs. Nguyen Thi Boc (ID Number 03110040), born in 1954, would like to borrow 1,972,000VND to purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell.

Mrs. Nguyen Thi Huong (ID Number 03110041), born in 1984, would like to borrow 1,972,000VND to invest in her cafe.

Mrs. Do Thi Mai (ID Number 03110037), born in 1977, would like to borrow 2,436,000VND to invest in her souvenir shop.

The total amount requested is 775USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

N. Thị Hiền (Ms 03110006), sinh năm 1979, mức vay:3.180.000 vnđ để đầu tư đi chợ. Đàn ông trong làng chị thường đi làm ở xưởng sắt tại Đa Hội, Đông Anh, Hà Nội, và chồng chị cũng vậy, hàng ngày anh vẫn đi làm sắt có thu nhập ổn định, bản thân chị vẫn đi chợ buôn bán hoa quả.Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.500.000 vnđ/tháng.Vợ chồng chị có hai con nhỏ, với mức thu nhập hiện tại thì việc hoàn trả vốn dần là rát dễ dàng và phù hợp với gia đình chị.Trong nhóm chị còn có: N. Thị Sử (Ms 03110036), sinh năm 1973, mức vay: 3.180.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn. N. Thị Bốc (Ms 03110040), sinh năm 1954, mức vay: 1.972.000 vnđ để đi chợ hoa quả. N. Thị Thu Hường (Ms 03110041), sinh năm 1984, mức vay: 1.1972.000 vnđ để đầu tư cửa hàng giải khát. Đỗ Thị Mai (Ms 03110037), sinh năm 1977, mức vay: 2.436.000 vnđ để đầu tư bán đồ lưu niệm.

loans.use: Selling fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Vumilia

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 30 year-old Vumilia M.. She is married and has three children ages seven, three, and one. In 2005 Vumilia established her clothes business. Working 6 days a week and five to eight hours a day, she earns about US $100 every month from this business. Vumilia requires a loan in order to buy more clothes in bulk. In the future, Vumilia plans to expand her business. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement

loans.use: To buy more clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Mwaji

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 26 year-old Mwaji M.. She is married and has one child, aged one. In 1999, Mwaji established her guest house business. Working seven days a week and sixteen to twenty-four hours a day, she earns about US $100 every month from this business. Mwaji has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to open another new business. In the future, Mwaji plans to invest in other businesses. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement

loans.use: To open other new businesses.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 30 year-old Mariam M.. She is married and has two children aged 7 and 11. In 2002 Mariam established her small shop. Working seven days a week, and thirteen to sixteen hours a day, she earns about US $30 every month from this business. Mariam requires a loan in order to buy more cooking oil, sugar, soaps, salt, and other utensils. She thanks you for your support.

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chili, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil, sugar, soaps, salt, and other utensils.

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Mrs. Em Y., 50, is a farmer and her husband is tuk-tuk taxi driver. Their combined income is $15 per day. The couple has five children, one of whom is married and lives in Toul Thnort Village, Kandal Province.

Y. owns a few oxen, which she uses to farm various kinds of fruit, including banana, jackfruit, and mango. Due to growing demand for her crops, Yeourn is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase wood. She will use the wood to build a stable for her oxen. The remainder of the loan will be used as working capital for her farming business. The loan will allow her to protect her business assets, and thereby increase the stability of her business.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To build a stable for her oxen

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 35 year-old Maria M.. She is married, and has two children aged 7 and 18. In 2005 Maria established her crops business. Working six days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $60 every month from this business. Maria requires a loan in order to buy more crops in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement

loans.use: To buy more crops in bulk.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 32 year-old Anna N.. She is a widow and has two children aged 11 and 13. In 2001 Anna established her grocery business. Working seven days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $130 every month from this business. Anna requires a loan in order to buy more stocks of beer and soft drinks. She thanks you for your support.

Her bar is a good place to chill with a beer if you manage to finish work early on a Friday afternoon. It’s the kind of place where you kick back on a plastic chair under a tree, with a local beer in hand, the aroma of roasting ‘mishikaki’ (kebabs made on an open fire) wafting around you, and talk to anyone and everyone who happens to wander by.

loans.use: To buy more stocks of beer and soft drinks.

loans.name: Yung

texts.en:
Mrs. Yung S., 37, sells perfume and similar goods and earns around $4 per day. She has been selling these kinds of goods for two years now. Her husband is a motorcycle taxi driver and earns around $2 per day. They live with six children in Toul Vihear Village, Kampong Cham Province. The family is also supported by her two daughters, one of whom is a face decorator and the other a tailor.

Now S. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase more perfume to sell. She will use the remainder of the loan to purchase face decorating tools for her daughter’s business.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase more perfume to sell

loans.name: Rozi

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 35 year-old Rose M.. She is married and has two children aged 5 and 15. In 2007, Rose established her rice selling business. Working six days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $100 every month from this business. Rose requires a loan in order to buy more stock of rice in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To buy more stocks of rice in bulk.

loans.name: Zunny

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 44 year-old Zunny M..  She is married, and has three children aged 14,17 and 24. She has two dependents who live with her because they are orphans.  In 2004, Zunny established her Mama Lishe/café business. Working seven days a week, and thirteen to sixteen hours a day, she earns about US $90 every month from this business. Zunny requires a loan in order to buy more kitchen utensils. In the future, Zunny plans to investing in other businesses. She thanks you for your support.  

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.use: To buy more kitchen utensils.

loans.name: Ket

texts.en:
Mrs. Ket C. is a broom-maker. Her husband transports the brooms to the local market to sell. Together they earn around $5 per day. The couple has three children, all of whom are in school. The family lives in Chmkar Samrong Village, Battambang Province.

Because their income is not sufficient to support the family’s expenses, she wants to pursue an additional business of oxen rental. Mrs. C. is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase an ox. She will then be able to rent out the ox to local farmers that need it to plow their fields, but cannot afford to purchase and take care of an ox on their own. By pursuing this business venture she hopes to increase her family income.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase an ox

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 38 year-old Jane  M..  She is married, and has three children aged 12,15 and 18. She has two dependents who live with her because they are orphans. In 2006, Jane  established her grocery business. Working seven days a week, and thirteen to sixteen hours a day, she earns about US $350 every month from this business. Jane  requires a loan in order to buy more stocks of beer and soft drinks in bulk. She thanks you for your support.  

Her bar is a good place to chill with a beer if you manage to finish work early on a Friday afternoon. It’s the kind of place where you kick back on a plastic chair under a tree, with a local beer in hand, the aroma of roasting ‘mishikaki’  (kebabs made on an open fire) wafting around you, and talk to anyone and everyone who happens to wander by.

loans.use: To buy more stocks of beer and soft drinks in bulk.

Tainess requires a loan in order to buy additional stocks of timber in bulk. She thanks you for your support.  

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To buy additional stocks of timber in bulk.

She thanks you for your support.  


The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chili, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To buy additional stocks of goods for her shop (general items like salt, sugar, soap, etc).

loans.name: Tiessiri (Courage) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Tiessiri group are married women with an average of 42 years of age and 7 children. They live with their husbands and children in polygamous families in Djinina, a village in the Fana area (Koulikoro region in Mali). The Tiessiri group trades various items: peanuts, cowpea flour, gathering products (shea tree), eggs, etc. This group is made up of relatives, neighbors and friends and has borrowed together from the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution for the past 3 years. This is their eighth group loan and all previous loans were refunded in time. The group members buy their peanut and cowpea supplies in Djinina and its surrounding villages. They each store their items in a joint store until they have sufficient quantities for sale. They usually carry out their cash sales on market days at the Fana and Marka coungo village stands to a mainly female customer base. For peanuts and cowpea supplies, their customers come to their village from many different areas such as Bamako, Koulikoro and Ségou. With this loan they would like to buy 120 kilogrammes of peanuts and 20 kilogrammes of cowpea, bought at an average costs of 275FCFA and resold at 375FCFA. This will allow them to attain an average monthly income of 20,000FCFA which will be help them build their businesses.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva translator

Les membres du groupe Tiessiri sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’age de 42 ans et 7 enfants .Elles vivent avec leurs maris et enfants dans des familles polygames à Djinina un village de la sous préfecture de Fana( Région de Koulikoro République du Mali) Le groupe Tiessiri fait le commerce d’articles divers : arachide, farine de niébé, produits de cueillette (zaban, karité) et des oeufs etc. Ce groupe constitué de consanguins de voisins et d’amies emprunte ensemble à l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. IL est à son huitième prêt solidaire et a correctement remboursé tous les précédents. Les membres se ravitaillent à Djinina sur place et dans les villages environnants pour l’arachide et le niébé .Elles disposent chacune dans sa concession conjugale d’un magasin dans lequel elles entreposent jusqu'à avoir la quantité destinée à la vente. Elles effectuent leurs ventes (articles divers : cueillette, ramassage etc.) généralement les jours de foire sous les hangars destinés à leur village à Fana et à Marka coungo au comptant à une clientèle féminine. Pour l’arachide et le niébé des clients de provenances différentes : Bamako, Koulikoro, Ségou etc viennent s’approvisionner auprès d’elles jusqu’au niveau du village. Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter : 120 kilogrammes d’arachide et 20 kilogrammes de niébé acheté à un prix moyen de 275FCFA et revendus à 375FCFA dégage un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20000fcfa qui servira à essentiellement renforcer les activités.

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Fanta's Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Tiessiri 2 group are married women with an average of 28 years of age and 5 children. They live in polygamous families in the village of Sikouna 2 in the Fana area (Koulikoro region in Mali). The main activity of this group of women is the sale of wood for heating, charcoal (which they sell to peasants in Sikouna 2 and in surrounding villages) and various other items (gathering products, etc). They have a stock room for the charcoal or keep the wood in front of their joint sales stands. They generally sell the charcoal for cash or credit in the village or wholesale to buyers from big cities like Ségou and Bamako, who also come to the village to buy cargoes of heating wood. Linked by professional and friendship ties, and very experienced in the business, the members of the group decided to request their first group loan from the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. They intend to buy 50 charcoal bags and 3 loads of heating wood and plan to attain an average monthly income of 12500FCFA, which will be used for paying the interest on the loan, providing for the needs of their families and especially for building their business activities.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

Les membres du groupe Tiessiri 2 sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’age de 28 ans et 5 enfants Elles vivent dans des familles polygames dans le village de Sikouna 2 sous préfecture de Fana( Région de Koulikoro République du Mali) L’activité principale de ce groupe de femmes Tiessiri 2 est la vente du bois de chauffe, du charbon de bois (qu’elles achètent avec les paysans sur place à Sikouna 2 et dans les villages environnants) et d’articles divers (produits de cueillettes etc.). Elles disposent d’un lieu de stockage dans pour le charbon de bois) ou devant (pour le bois de chauffe) les concessions conjugales pour le stockage de leurs marchandises. Elles vendent généralement le charbon de bois à détail au comptant et à crédit à domicile (au village) et en gros aux forains venant des grandes villes comme Ségou et Bamako, qui viennent également jusqu’au village pour faire leurs cargaisons en bois de chauffe au comptant. Unies par des liens professionnels, de voisinage et très expérimentés dans les activités économiques, les membres du groupe ont décidé ensemble de solliciter la collaboration de l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur premier prêt solidaire. Elles comptent acheter 50 sacs de charbon de bois 3 chargements de bois de chauffe et envisagent réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 12500FCFA. qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux besoins de la famille et surtout renforcer les activités.

loans.use: Purchase of coal and heating wood

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophal S., 50, and her husband, Mr. Nha In, 50, who live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1975 and have four children, three sons and one daughter. One of her children has full-time employment and the other three are enrolled in a local school.

Mrs. Sophal has been farming for over ten years. She grows melons, papayas, and corn in her farm not so far from her house. Her husband is a fisherman and does construction work when he has free time.

Sophal is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to purchase a boat for her husband's fishing, build a shelter for cows, and pay fees for renting more plots of land for farming.

loans.use: To purchase a boat for fishing, build a shelter for cows, and rent more plots of land for farming

loans.name: Ayesha's Group

texts.en:
Ayesha baji is the wife of N. M. and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She has six children and owns a two-room brick house where she has lived for 10 years. For the last five years, her husband has made a living as a watchman.

In addition to taking care of her children and doing housework, Ayesha baji produces and sells milk. She has successfully repaid three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan), and is now applying for a new loan to buy an additional buffalo to increase her production of milk.

She is joined in her loan group by a four other people. Samina baji wants a loan to buy tools. Fatima baji, Zareena baji and Nusrat baji each want a loan to buy a buffalo for their own milk-producing businesses.

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Thuy Mai's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thuy Mai, born in 1970 (ID Number: 10040024), wants to borrow 4,452,000VND to expand her hair salon. Beside this shop, she also sells drinks so she has a stable daily income. Her husband works in an advertising agent, earning stable income. Her family's average monthly income is 3,000,000VND (about 188USD). She likes to join this Fund because she can repay the loan on an installment basis. Her group also consists of:

Mrs. N. Thi Thu Huong (ID Number: 10040026), born in 1980, wants to borrow 3,604,000VND to invest in selling furniture and electronic products.

Mrs. N. Thi Thuy Ngan (ID Number: 10040025), born in 1982, wants to borrow 3,604,000VND to invest in a breakfast eatery.

Mrs. P. Thu N. (ID Number: 10040042), born in 1960, wants to borrow 2,204,000VND to invest in selling drinks.

Mrs. T. Thi Thu Ha (ID Number: 10040028), born in 1971, wants to borrow 4,028,000VND to invest in breeding pigs.

The total amount requested is 1,075USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chồng chị làm nghề quảng cáo với mức lương ổn định. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.000.000 vnđ / tháng. Việc vay vốn trả dần là rất phù hợp với gia đình chị nên chị rất thích và mong muốn được vay vốn thường xuyên. Nguyễn Thị Thuý Ngân(Ms 10040025), sinh năm 1982, mức vay: 3.604.000 vnđ để bán hàng ăn sáng. P. Thị Nguyện(Ms 10040042), sinh năm 1960, mức vay 2.204.000 vnđ để đầu tư bán hàng giải khát. Trịnh Thị Thu Hà(Ms 10040028), sinh năm 1971, mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn.

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji is the wife of H. Muhammad and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She and her husband have no children, but run a livestock business and treat their animals as if they were children. Parveen has successfully repaid four loans from Asasah (a micorofinance institute in Pakistan), and is now applying for a new loan to buy another buffalo so that she can produce and sell additional milk.

Parveen has three other people in her loan group. Aimna baji, Naseem baji, Zahoor baji and Amna baji each want a loan to buy a buffalo for their own milk-producing businesses.

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Ruqaiya's Group

texts.en:
Ruqaiya baji is the wife of M. Hanif and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She has ten children, and her husband is a land owner and farmer. Ruqaiya baji and her older daughter make a living sewing clothes and doing embroidery. Ruqaiya has successfully repaid four loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a new loan for her husband, who wants to buy another buffalo to increase his production of milk.

Ruquiya is making this application with three other people. Hafizan baji, Jamila baji and Nusrat baji each want a loan to buy a buffalo for their own milk-producing businesses.

This is a group loan, and funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Sharifan's Group

texts.en:
Sharifan baji is the wife of A. A. and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She has two sons and runs a livestock business, selling milk produced by the buffaloes she owns. Her husband is a land owner and farmer. Sharifan has successfully repaid one loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan), and has now applied for a second to buy another buffalo to expand her production of milk.

She is joined in her loan group by three other people. Naziran baji, another woman also named Naziran baji and Bashiran baji each want a loan to buy a buffalo so that they can expand their own milk production.

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Vang

texts.en:
Mrs. Vang N., 58, is a widow who lives in a small village across the Mekong River about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. She has seven children, five sons and two daughters. Three of her children are married and live outside the family home. One son is a construction worker, another one sells silk products, and the last one weaves silk at home.

Since she was young, Mrs. Vang has been a silk weaver, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh.

She is requesting a loan of US$ 600 to purchase silk materials for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loans.name: Tito

texts.en:
Mr. Tito B. (not shown in the picture), 35, and his wife, Mrs. Chanthol Touch (shown in the picture with her son), 30, who live in a Phnom Penh suburb married in 2001 and have three sons.

Mr. Tito has been a driver for a factory for six years, while Mrs. Chanthol used to be a garment factory worker for many years but now she has stopped for a while to take care of her little son. Tito is requesting a loan of US$ 300 to add to his own money to purchase a motorcycle scooter to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle scooter to drive to work

loans.name: Saira's Group

texts.en:
Saira baji is the wife of M. Aslam and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She is the mother of seven children, and her husband makes a living running a shop that sells schoolbags. Saira baji is an independent woman with her own milk-selling business. She has successfully repaid one loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan), and is now applying for a second loan to buy another buffalo to increase her production of milk.

There are four other people in her loan group. Zeenat baji , Bushra baji, Rehana baji and Zainab baji each want a use their loan to buy buffalo for their own milk-selling businesses.

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Sean

texts.en:
Mr. Sean S., 38, and his wife, Mrs. Sophal Chi, 29, who live in a small village off of National Road Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh, married in 1999 and have four children: one son and three daughters. Two of them are in local school.

Mr. Sean has been growing vegetables (see photo) for twenty years. His wife has been selling vegetables for seventeen years. She buys them from Ta Khmao market and some from her own farm and carries them on her motorcycle for re-sale in Phnom Penh.

Mr. Sean is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase a new motorcycle to replace their old one and to expand his wife's business.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike and expand their business selling vegetables

loans.name: Phoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Phoeun P., 51, is a widow with five children, two sons and three daughters, who lives in a small village across the Mekong River about twenty kilometers north of Phnom Penh. Three of her daughters are married and live outside the family home and the other two have full-time employment.

For eleven years, Mrs. Phoeun has been a silk weaver, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Now she is requesting a loan of US$ 400 to purchase silk material to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen baji is the wife of M.Rafique and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She is the mother of four sons and three daughters. For the last six years, her husband has made a living running a clothing-making business. Nasreen has successfully repaid one loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan), and is now applying for a new loan so her husband can buy more garments and expand his business.

Nasreen is applying for this loan with six other people. Shahida baji wants a loan for her gold business. Abida baji wants a loan to make additional garments to sell. Haleema baji wants to buy a thread-making machine. Tahira baji wants to buy supplies for her food stall. Umran baji wants to buy cloth to make handkerchiefs. Naseem baji wants to buy a machine to stitch borders on scarves and shirts.

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Keang

texts.en:
Mrs. Keang S.,39, and her husband, Mr. Mengtich Ly, 49, who live in a small village about seventeen kilometers south of Phnom Penh, married in 1990 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. Three of them are in local school.

Mrs. Keang has been selling vegetables for two years. She buys them from Ta Khmao market for re-sale at the market in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a motor taxi driver for fifteen years. His motorcycle scooter is very old and breaks down very often.

So, Keang is requesting a loan of US$ 1200 to purchase a new motorcycle to replace the old one for her husband to drive as a motor taxi and to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike for running a motor taxi and expand business of selling vegetables

loans.name: Louy

texts.en:
Mrs. Louy L., 55, and her husband, Mr. Khoun Khem, 58, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about twenty kilometers north of Phnom Penh, married in 1971 and have eight children, four sons and four daughters. Four of their children are married and live outside the family home. One son has full-time employment, one is a fisherman, one daughter weaves silk, and the youngest one is in school.

Since she was young, Mrs. Louy has been a silk weaver, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Mr. Khoun has been a fisherman since he was young as well.

Now Louy is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to add to her own money for building a house for her daughter who got married and is in the process of building her house.

loans.use: To add to her own money for building a house for her daughter

loans.name: Samnang

texts.en:
Mr. Samnang B., 41, and his wife, Mrs. Chanthorn Mob, 43, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1990 and have five children, four sons and one daughter. The first son does construction work with his father, and two other children are in local school.

Mr. Samnang has been a mason for sixteen years. He does his work in the village and nearby province while his wife stays at home taking care of their children. The couple is in the process of building their new house and they need a loan to finish it.

Samnang is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to make a stair rail and wall of the house and fill in the ground.

loans.use: To build a stair rail and wall of their house and fill in the ground

loans.name: Jamila's Group

texts.en:
Jamila baji is the wife of U. and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She is the mother of six children and runs a thread-making business. Her husband runs a power loom. She is applying for a loan to buy another power loom for her husband.

She is making this loan with four other people. Kosar baji wants a loan for her own power loom business. Naseem baji wants a loan for her business selling utensils. Farhat baji wants a loan to buy land. Sajida baji wants a loan to buy more supplies for her carpet-making business.

This is a group loan. The funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Run

texts.en:
Mrs. Run K., 43, and her husband, Mr. Yul San, 47, who live along National Road Number Five about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1986 and have four children, two sons and two daughters. Two of their children have full-time employment, one is in school, and the youngest one stays at home.

Mrs. Run and her husband have been selling firewood for eight years. Mr. Yul travels to buy their goods from other provinces for Run to sell at their house. The business is running very well and the couple needs more money to expand their business.

So, Run is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase a machine for cutting firewood and to buy more firewood for re-sale.

loans.use: To purchase a machine for cutting firewood and buy more firewood for re-sale

loans.name: Sarum

texts.en:
Mr. Sarum K. (shown in the picture with his mother), 32, and his wife, who live on an island in the MeK. River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 2000 and have two daughters. Sarum is living with his mother who is a silk weaver.

Since he was married, Mr. Sarum has been a silk weaver, a skill he learned from his mother, and his wife is a silk weaver as well. The couple sells their finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh.

He is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase silk materials for his weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loans.name: Rani's Group

texts.en:
Rani baji is married to M. and lives in the city of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She has five children, three of whom are married. Another makes a living driving a donkey cart. Her husband sells utensils, a job he has had for the last five years. Rani has successfully paid back a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan), and is applying for a new loan to buy more utensils for her husband to sell.

She is making this application with four other people. Abida baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine. Maqsoodan baji wants a loan to buy more material for her carpet-making business. Rashidan baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo so she can sell its milk. Nazmin baji wants a loan to buy additional inventory for her grocery shop. Shamim baji wants a loan for her small milk-selling business.

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Najma's Group

texts.en:
Najma baji is the wife of M. A. and lives in the city of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She is the mother of eight children, and owns a two-room brick house. For the past five years, her husband has made a living selling fruit. Najma has successfully completed her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a new loan to buy more fruits for her husband to sell.

She is making this application with three other people. Jamila baji wants a loan to buy more fruit to sell from her stand. Bilquis baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo so she can sell its milk. Razia baji wants a loan to buy more material for her embroidery business.

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Samina's Group

texts.en:
Samina baji is the wife of M. U. and lives in the city of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house where she has lived for the last six years. She has three sons. Her husband has a food business and also runs a drink stand. Samina has successfully repaid three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan), and has applied for a fourth loan to buy more material for her husband’s food business.

She is applying for this loan with three other people. Shahida baji wants a loan to buy more items to sell from her fruit stand. Nusrat baji wants a loan to buy more inventory for her grocery shop. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo so she can sell its milk..

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Zakia's Group

texts.en:
Zakia baji is the wife of R. A. and has lived in a two-room brick house in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan for the last 10 years. She has three daughters and one son, all of whom are enrolled in a local school. Zakia baji sews clothes and does domestic chores for a living. Her husband runs a grocery store. She has successfully paid back three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) and is now applying for a fourth loan to buy more inventory for her husband’s shop.

She is applying for her loan with several other people. Salma baji wants a loan to buy more materials for her wood business. Bushra baji wants a loan to buy more tents for her tent-service business. Rubina baji and Tahira baji want a loan to buy more fruit for their fruit-selling businesses.

This is a group loan. The funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem baji is the wife of M. and lives in the city of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She has lived in a two-room brick house for the last 22 years, and is the mother of four sons. Her oldest son works in a factory. The next oldest son raises buffalos. Her younger children are enrolled in a local neighborhood school. Her husband is a land owner who farms for a living.

Naseem baji contributes to the family income by running a milk business. She has successfully repaid three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) and is applying for a new loan to buy a buffalo to expand her small company. She is making this application with two other people. Sharifan baji also wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk business. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy wood to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Rani's Group

texts.en:
Rani baji is married to A. M. and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has no children. Her husband runs a livestock business, and has been in this profession for the last 10 years. Rani has successfully repaid three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a new loan to buy a buffalo to raise and resell.

She is making this application with several other people. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk business. Shafqat baji wants a loan to buy wheat to resell. Amna baji wants a loan to buy more inventory for her grocery store. Iram baji wants a loan to buy more supplies for her fruit business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Habijan's Group

texts.en:
Habijan baji is the wife of B. A. and lives in the city of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She has lived in a two-room brick house for the last 35 years, and is the mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. Her husband is a land contractor (he rents land and farms it). He has worked in this area for the last 25 years. Habijan has successfully repaid three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) and is now applying for a loan to rent land for her husband.

She is applying for this loan with several other people. Sugran baji wants a loan to rent land. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy wood for her furniture business. Sugran baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo to resell. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy inventory for her grocery store.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.fr:
Born on September 25, 1972 in Wahala, in the Plateaux region in TOGO, Ms. Adjoa D. got married to Mr. Koffi GADJEZO, who is a mechanic. She has two children. Established for five years in the Agoè district, she sells charcoal near the marketplace of this district. She wishes to include commerce in corn and yams and is requesting this initial loan to do so. The loan would be used to buy 40 yam tubers and 5 sacks of corn in order to satisfy her customers better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Née le 25 septembre 1972 à Wahala dans la région des plateaux au TOGO, dame D. Adjoa s’est mariée à monsieur GADJEZO Koffi qui est un mécanicien et a deux enfants. Installée dans le quartier d’Agoè à proximité du marché dudit quartier depuis plus de cinq ans, elle vend du charbon. Elle désire ajouter le commerce du maïs et d’igname et sollicite à cet effet ce premier crédit pour acheter 40 tubercules d’ignames et 6 sacs de maïs afin de mieux satisfaire ses clients.

loans.use: To buy tubers and corn

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en: Dorothy is a forty-year-old mother of six children. She lives in Kisumu, Kenya with her family. She is the proprietor of a food kiosk established in 1999. She specializes in making chapattis, the local favorites, which she serves with boiled beans and green lentils to her clients. She  also makes mandazis, normally served with tea. Her business has flourished over the last nine years and this she attributes to four microfinance loans received from KMET/KIVA. She now requires an additional US $800 for expansion.

loans.use: Expand her business

loans.name: Koffi Mawuli

texts.fr:
Koffi Mawuli A. was born on August 3, 1955 in Notsè, in Halo Prefecture, in Togo. He is married and the father of six children, the care of whom falls upon his shoulders. He opened a sales center for school supplies in the Agoè district. The objective for which he created this center is to be near the people in his district, because there is no bookstore in the area. During this time of vacations, the price of school supplies has diminished a little, and he wishes to take advantage of this chance to stock up on books and notebooks before school starts. To do so, he is requesting this loan to buy 5 boxes of notebooks and 80 books for primary school. He will thus be able to earn a good income.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Monsieur A. Koffi Mawuli est né le 03 août 1955 à Notsè dans la préfecture de Haho au Togo. Il est marié et père de six enfants dont la charge lui incombe. Il a ouvert un centre de vente des fournitures scolaires dans le quartier d’Agoè. L’objectif pour lequel il a crée ce centre est d’être plus proche de la population de son quartier car il n’ y a de librairie dans la localité. Pendant ces vacances, le prix des fournitures a un peu diminué et il désire profiter de cette occasion pour faire un stock de cahiers et de livres avant l’approche des rentrées scolaires. A cet effet, il sollicite ce crédit pour acheter 5 cartons de cahiers et 80 unités de livres des cours primaires. Ainsi il pourra gagner un bon revenu.

loans.use: To buy school supplies

loans.name: Anna

texts.en: Anna is a 60-year-old widow who supports six children in her household. She runs a business on a small scale. Anna owns ten housing units which she rents out at US $12 a month. She is able to generate US $804 in rent a month. She has received and fully paid US $1587 loans from KMET/ KIVA. She has currently applied for US $800 to enable her to improve the condition of her houses.

loans.use: House renovation

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine is a 34-year-old hard-working entrepreneur. She is married and lives with her husband and 4 children in Kisumu, Kenya. She has been in the second-hand clothing business for many years. She specializes in selling both men's and women's clothes. She also runs a tailoring and dressmaking shop. Christine, who has received three loans from KMET/Kiva, now requires US $800 to boost her tailoring business and also add more stock of second-hand clothes.

loans.use: Invest in her tailoring shop

loans.name: Pierrette

texts.fr:
Born on January 19, 1954 in AGOHOE BALIME, in the neighboring country of Bénin, Ms. Pierrette became settled in Lomé in 1995 and married Mr. ADOKOU, who is a retiree. Her work is in selling basic provisions in the Adidogomé district in Lomé. She is requesting this initial loan to buy 50 yam tubers, 4 sacks of corn, and 1 sack of charcoal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Née le 19 janvier 1953 à AGOHOE BALIME dans le pays voisin au Bénin?, dame Pierrette s’est installée à Lomé depuis 1995 et s’est mariée à monsieur ADOKOU qui est un retraité. Elle a pour a pour activité la vente des produits de premières nécessités dans le quartier d’Adidogomé à Lomé. Elle sollicite ce premier crédit pour acheter 50 tubercules d’ignames, 4 sacs de maïs et 1 sacs de charbon.

loans.use: To buy tubers, grains, and charcoal

loans.name: Massan

texts.fr:
Born in 1982, Mrs. Massan K. was not successful in her studies due to the lack of financial support. She became involved with the making of cassava flour, “garri”, which is very well-liked in the area. Married to a tailor, she is the mother of three (3) children. She contributes to the costs of the household thanks to the income from her business. A very energetic woman, she manages her business very well and is requesting a loan that will allow her to purchase large quantities of cassava. With this loan, she will be able to increase her income and thus better contribute to the improvement of her family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by Allana Carlyle, Kiva Volunteer.

Née en 1982, Madame K. Massan n’a pas fait de brillantes études par manque de support financier. Elle s’est lancée dans la fabrication de la farine de manioc « gari » qui est très appréciée dans le milieu. Mariée à un tailleur, elle est mère de trois (3) enfants. Elle contribue aux charges du foyer grâces aux revenus de son activité. Dynamique, elle gère bien ses activités et sollicite un financement qui va lui servir d’acheter en grande quantité le manioc. Par ce crédit, elle pourra augmenter son revenu pour mieux contribuer à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.

loans.use: The purchase of cassava for processing into cassava flour

loans.name: Yawa Dzidedi

texts.fr:
Ms. Yawa Dzidedi K. was born in 1958 in Kévé, a town located 40 km from Lomé. She is married to Mr. Kossi DOUHO and has two children. She works in selling basic provisions in the Adidogomé district. She produces fruit juice and ice cubes. She is requesting this initial loan to diversify her sales by buying 10 sacks of rice and 40 yam tubers. And so, with the income from this business, she will be able to help her husband with family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Dame K. yawa Dzidedi est née en 1958 à Kévé localité située à 40 Km de Lomé. Elle s’est mariée à monsieur DOUHO Kossi et a deux enfants. Elle a pour activité la vente des produits de premières nécessités dans le quartier d’Adidogomé. Elle fait la fabrication des jus de fruits et de glaçon. Elle sollicite ce premier crédit pour diversifier ses ventes par l’achat de 10 sacs de riz et 40 tubercules d’ignames. Ainsi avec le revenu de cette activité, elle pourra aider son mari dans les dépenses de sa famille.

loans.use: To buy essential goods

loans.name: Yaovi

texts.fr:
Born in Gamé Séva in 1977, Mr. Yaovi A. left school early in life to become a farmer so he could make ends meet. Married with two children, he is a strong, hardworking man who is expert at farming corn. He is requesting a loan so he can increase the size of his corn field, which will provide him with more revenue thus allowing him to effectively meet his family’s needs.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Né à Gamé Séva en 1977, Monsieur A.. Yaovi a très tôt abandonné ses études pour se lancer dans l’agriculture afin de mieux subvenir à ses besoins. Marié et père de deux (2) enfants, c’est un homme valide, travailleur qui maîtrise bien la culture du maïs. Pour agrandir son champ, il sollicite un crédit qui va l’aider à augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour renforcer son revenu dans le but de subvenir efficacement aux besoins de la famille.

loans.use: To increase the size of his corn field

loans.name: Abra

texts.fr:
Born in 1981 in Gamé (P/Zio), Mrs. Abra D. is married and supports two people. Her main occupation is growing corn. She is able to contribute to her household with her income. She is seeking a loan that will allow her to expand her cultivatable land and buy fertilizer to enrich the soil.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer.

Née en 1981 à Gamé (P/Zio), Madame D. Abra est mariée et a à sa charge deux (2) personnes. Son activité principale est la culture de maïs. Avec son revenu, elle arrive à contribuer aux charges du foyer. Elle sollicite un crédit qui va lui permettre d’augmenter sa surface cultivable et acheter des engrais pour rendre le sol plus fertile.

loans.use: To expand cultivatable land

loans.name: Kodjo

texts.fr:
Mr. Kodjo B. was born in 1969. Having not had the opportunity to go to school, he took up working the land. Having grown almost everything to earn money, he put special emphasis on growing corn. A married father of four, he is able to provide for his family with his minimum wages. Very dutiful and sensible, he manages his business well and seeks funding to allow him to expand his corn field and thus increase his sales to improve his family’s lifestyle.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer.

Monsieur B. Kodjo est née en 1969. N’ayant pas eu la chance de faire de brillantes études, il a embrassé le travail de la terre. Cultivant presque tout pour se procurer de revenus, il a mis un accent particulier sur la culture du maïs. Marié et père de quatre (4) enfants, il arrive à subvenir aux besoins de sa famille grâce à son revenu minimum. Très dévoué et sage dans ses réactions, il gère bien ses activités et sollicite un financement qui pourra lui permettre d’agrandir son champ de maïs et par conséquent augmenter son chiffre d’affaires pour mieux contribuer à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.

loans.use: To expand cultivatable land

loans.name: Massan

texts.fr:
Mrs. Massan E. was born in 1971. Her main business is processing manioc flour. Married and the mother of five children, she has mastered her trade. A good manager, she has been successful in combining other small businesses. With the revenues from her business, she has been able to help manage the family expenses. An honest woman, she has successfully managed and paid back her first loan without defaulting. Currently, she is taking out another loan that will allow her to promote her business by purchasing a large quantity of manioc.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva volunteer.

Madame E. Massan est née en 1971. Son activité principale est la transformation de la farine de manioc. Mariée et mère de cinq (5) enfants, elle maîtrise bien son activité. Bonne gestionnaire, elle arrive à associer d’autres petits commerce. Elle partage les charges du foyer par les revenus qu’elle tire de son activité. Honnête, elle a su bien géré son premier crédit et l’a remboursé sans incident. A présent, elle sollicite un autre crédit qui va lui permettre de promouvoir son activité en achetant en grande quantité le manioc.

loans.use: Promote the processing of manioc flour

loans.name: Essi

texts.fr:
Mrs. Essi K. was born in 1982. She is married and the mother of two children. She has proven her drive with her participation in managing the family expenses. A good manager and a master of her business, she is asking for a loan that will serve to finance an expansion of her corn field. With this, she will be able to increase her revenues in order to further contribute in the improvement of her family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva volunteer.

Madame K. Essi est née en 1982, mariée, est mère de deux (2) enfants. Elle fait preuve de son dynamisme par sa participation dans les charges du foyer. Bonne gestionnaire et maîtrisant bien son activité, elle sollicite un financement qui va lui permettre d’agrandir son champ de maïs. Par ceci, elle pourra augmenter ses revenus afin de contribuer davantage dans l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.

loans.use: Expansion of corn field

loans.name: Nelly

texts.es:
Nelly is a good client, very hard-working.  She has three children to support; her husband is a driver.  She works from very early in the morning until very late at night, in different parts of the city of El Alto.  She's an unassuming woman and very commited to working because she wants her children to know that with a little sacrifice one can get ahead in life in an honest way.
Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer
Es una buena cliente es muy trabajadora ella tiene tres niños que mantiene, su esposo se dedica a 

manejar una movilidad, trabaja desde muy temprano hasta muy altas horas de la noche en distintas 

zonas de la Ciudad de el Alto es de clase sencilla y muy responsable en su trabajo, ya que quiere 

demostrar a sus hijos que con un poco de sacrificio se puede salir en la vida en una forma honesta.

loans.use: Increase working capital.

loans.name: Akoua

texts.fr:
Born in 1951, Mrs. Akoua A. is married to a tailor. She works in agriculture, which ultimately does not allow her, along with her husband, to manage the household expenses for their five children. With the help of her husband, she has opened a small general food store. She has already paid back one loan successfully. Currently, she is asking for a new loan that will allow her to stock her store with soap, dough, tin cans, and other goods demanded by her clients.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva volunteer.

Née en 1951, Madame A. Akoua est mariée à un tailleur. Elle pratique l’agriculture qui finalement ne l’aide pas suffisamment à partager avec son mari les charges de ses cinq (5) enfants. Avec l’aide de son mari, elle a ouvert une petite boutique d’alimentation générale. Elle a à son actif un crédit qui a été bien remboursé. A présent, elle sollicite un nouveau crédit qui va lui servir d’approvisionner sa boutique en savon, pâte, boîte de conserve, et autres sur la demande de sa clientèle.

loans.use: Stock general food store

loans.name: Mario

texts.es:
Mario is a milk producer for the PIL company; he also works in bovine artificial insemination. His wife sells potato and potato flour products that they themselves produce on their land and they sell them to different markets in nearby communities. With these jobs they are able to support their four children, all of whom are dependent on their parents.

Mario lives in a community called Huayrocondo-Battallas (located two and a half hours from La Paz city).

The loan will be used to buy a medium-sized cow to increase milk production, and the milk will be then sold to the PIL company. This will increase his income by about 15%.

This is Mario’s second loan with Impro, and the good payment history enables him to qualify for another loan. Mario has been a client of IMPRO since April, 2007.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

Mario, es productor de leche de vaca que comercializa en la empresa PIL; también trabaja realizando inseminación artificial, la esposa es comerciante de papa y chuño productos que ellos mismos producen en su tierra y venden en las diferentes ferias de las comunidades aledañas. Así consiguen sus ingresos con los que cubren la manutención de sus cuatro hijos que depende de ellos.

Mario vive en la Comunidad de Huayrocondo - Batallas (A dos horas y media de la ciudad de La Paz).

El crédito lo destinará para la compra de una vaca de raza mediana para incrementar la producción de leche y vender a la Fabrica PIL. De esta manera sus ingresos mejorarán en al menos un 15% más.

Es el Segundo crédito con Impro, el buen comportamiento de pago permite aprobar otro préstamo solicitado por Mario. Es cliente de IMPRO desde Abril del año 2007.

loans.use: Buy a milk cow to increase milk production and sell the milk to PIL company.

loans.name: Olga Maria

texts.es:
Olga is a humble client of scarse resources who supports her three school-age children. Her husband helps her with his income. She works in a cellular phone store, which is her only job, since she was unable to have other opportunities to improve her quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: Purchase a calling center, as well as phone cards to sell.

loans.name: Alma Rosa

texts.es:
Alma began her business to provide a better future for her 2 children. She wasn’t able to find work and wanted to have her children nearby in order to take care of them, so she began a business in 2006 selling food. She sold food to her neighbors and thanks to her great cooking she gained clients and is making good income.

She needs a loan for US$250, which will be repaid in 3 months, to buy ingredients to make food and be able to sell more in order to earn a greater income. With your help Alma will be successful.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

Alma inicio el negocio para salir adelante con sus 2 hijos, ya que no encontraba trabajo y queria tener a sus hijos cerca para cuidarlos.Comenzó su negocio en el año 2006 vendiendo comida a sus vecinos y gracias a su buen sazon se fue haciendo de clientes, obteniendo buenas ganancias.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar materia prima y poder vender mas para tener mejores ganancias. Con tu ayuda Alma saldra delante.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients to make food

loans.name: Abravi

texts.fr:
Born in 1978, Mrs. Abravi E. is a seller of foodstuffs (rice, beans). Married and the mother of three children, she helps manage the family expenses thanks to the revenues from her sales. She is asking for a loan that will allow her to purchase sacks of rice, beans and other items to prepare in order to enlarge her business, better serve her clients, and ultimately strengthen her business.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva volunteer.

Née en 1978, Madame E. Abravi est une revendeuse de denrée alimentaire (riz, haricot). Mariée et mère de trois (3) enfants, elle arrive à contribuer aux charges du foyer grâce au revenu de sa vente. En d’agrandir son activité et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, elle sollicite un crédit qui va lui servir de renforcer ses activités en achetant des sacs de riz, de haricot et autres pour sa préparation.

loans.use: Expand business of foodstuffs

loans.name: Juan German

texts.es:
Juan began his business in order to support his children and give them an education as he wishes a better quality of life for them. He began his grocery store in 2006 with little merchandise, and little by little he bought more items that people requested, until he was able to fully establish his store.

He needs a loan for US$250, which will be repaid in 3 months, to stock merchandise and be able to sell more, thereby improving his income. With your help Juan will be able to grow his business.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

Juan inicio el negocio para poder mantener a sus hijos y darles educacion, ya que desea una mejor calidad de vida para ellos. Comenzo su tienda de abarrotes en el año 2006 con poca mercancia y poco a poco fue comprando mercancia que la gente le solictaba, hasta que logro tener su tienda mas establecida.

El necesita un prestamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para surtir mercancia y poder vender mas y mejorar sus ingresos. Con tu apoyo Juan hara crecer su negocio.

loans.use: Buy merchandise to sell in his store

loans.name: Amuda Layi Group

texts.en: Sahadatu is the leader of a six-member group. She is a 70-year-old wife and the mother of three children. The group consists of five women and one man. They are very hard-working and resourceful family providers. They trade in various commodities like kola nuts, palm kernel oil, food stuffs, clothing, etc. to earn a living. Their major challenge has to do with funds to grow these businesses to the expected levels to redeem their families from poverty. They believe the loan will impact their businesses to bring a transformation in their family well-being. Their common hope is to be able to increase savings to provide their children with quality education. They want to use the loan to procure an increased stock of kola nuts, clothing, food stuffs, palm kernel oil, etc. They belong to the group called ‘Amuda Layi Trust Group’. Members in this group agree to guarantee for one another as a social collateral and assist one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To procure an increased stock of kola nuts,  food stuffs, palm kernel oil, etc.

loans.name: Fuente De Esperanza (Source Of Hope) Group 4

texts.en:
Delfina is the president of the ¨Fuente de Esperanza¨ Bank of Hope and definitely holds sway in her community. She lives in a very poor community surrounded by sugar cane in a rural area outside of El Seibo. Delfina is 77 years old and lives with her husband. She has six children and six grandchildren who now live in the neighboring towns of Higuey and La Romana.

Delfina sells clothing, mainly shirts, to the people in her community. She has successfully repaid two loans to Esperanza International and is now requesting a third. With the loan money, she hopes to open a small ¨colmado¨ (mini grocery-store) at the side of her house.

Note: This is a group loan for 5 people.

loans.use: To open a mini grocery-store at the side of her house.

loans.name: Liliana

texts.es:
Liliana has worked for years in a well-known popular market in the city. She is the mother of 5 school-aged children. She earns her income from selling breakfasts in the morning and teas in the afternoons. Her home is located in El Alto city. Every morning she gets up very early to go in to the city, accompanying her two small daughters as they are too young to be left alone. With her loan she will buy consumables to sell and thereby be able to give a better education to her children.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

La Sra. Liliana, trabaja hace años en un conocido mercado popular de la ciudad, es madre de 5 hijos en edad escolar, ingreso es de la venta de desayunos en las mañanas y te por la tarde Su domicilio se encuentra en la ciudad de El Alto, cada mañana se levanta muy temprano para bajar a la ciudad en compañía de sus dos pequeñas hijas ya que son muy pequeñas para dejar las solas. Con el crédito comprara insumos para sus ventas y asi poder dar una mejor educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase consumables

loans.name: Afi

texts.fr:
Born in Ghana in 1968, Mrs. Afi K. is married and the mother of one child. Her main business is to sell cakes made with a manioc base. As she is very driven, she manages her business well. She is asking for a loan that will allow her to purchase a large quantity of manioc and oil, as well as start other businesses in order to increase her revenues and better provide for the needs of her family.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva volunteer.

Née au Ghana en 1968, Madame K. Afi est mariée et mère d’un (1) enfant. Son activité principale est la vente de gâteau fabriqué à base du manioc. Très dynamique, elle gère bien ses activités. Elle sollicite un financement qui va lui permettre d’acheter en grande quantité du manioc et de l’huile et aussi initier d’autres activités afin d’augmenter ses revenus et mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.

loans.use: Buy manioc to produce cake

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.es:
María Luisa began her business helping her husband and improving their quality of life. As he didn’t have a job, she helped him by beginning to sell tamales. She began her business in 2005 with the money she had saved and decided to invest in the ingredients to make tamales, and she began to sell them.

She needs a loan for US$250, which will be repaid in 3 months, to buy ingredients and be able to improve her sales and make her business successful. With your help she will be able to accomplish her goals.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

Maria Luisa inicio el negocio para ayudar a su pareja y mejora su estilo de vida, ya que el no tenia trabajo y para ayudarle ella empezo a vender tamales.Comenzo su negocio en el año 2005 con dinero que tenia ahorrado y decidio invertirlo en materia prima para la elaboracion de tamales y empezo a venderlos.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar materia prima y poder mejorar sus ventas y salir adelante. Con tu ayuda ella podra lograrlo.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients to make tamales

loans.name: Abra

texts.fr:
Mrs. Abra F. was born in Lonyo in the prefecture of Zio in 1949. She is married and the mother of six children. Thanks to her revenues from her agriculture business, she is able to help manage the household expenses. She has a lot of experience in agricultural work and has mastered the production of corn and other crops. For this reason, she is asking for a loan to finance the expansion of her cultivable land. She will therefore increase her revenues to improve the living conditions for her family.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva volunteer.

Madame F. Abra est née à Lonyo (P/Zio) en 1949. Mariée et mère de six (6) enfants, elle arrive à contribuer aux charges du foyer grâce aux revenus tirés de son activité : l’agriculture. Elle a beaucoup d’expérience dans les travaux agricoles et maîtrise bien la production du maïs et autres cultures. Ainsi, sollicite t-elle un financement qui va lui permettre d’étendre sa superficie cultivable. Elle pourra donc augmenter ses revenus pour améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.

loans.use: Expand cultivable land

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya is an entrepreneur from Nikopol where she owns a small grocery sales business. She is married with two sons. Natalya has a vending facility in a favorable location. Competition in this sphere of trade is relatively low. Natalya has been in business for a year. Her monthly income is about $500.

Natalya's business has a very good reputation in the market. She is very determined and strongly believes best results are gained by focused and sustained efforts, which is why she always presses on to achieve even bigger success in her business. Natalya is hoping to grow her business and make all her dreams come true. She is requesting a loan of 3500 Grivnas to increase her turnover capital.

loans.use: To increase turnover capital

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is married and has two children.
